characters: THE BEST LITTLE WHOREHOUSE IN TEXAS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Jack Roy Wallace and Miss Wulla Jean pose with th girls on the front porch of the house as a photographer takes their picture with an old flash-powder camera.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Sheriff Jack Roy Wallace picked it out for Miss Wulla Jean and her girls in 1910 when they moved there from over the hardware store on Main Street. We pan down through the leaves of a tree to reveal two gi working in a little garden by the side of the house. It h the appearance of a turn-of-the-century ladies college as the other girls cut flowers, sit around the grape arbor a sun-dry their long hair. (NOTE: We can bleed in the color slowly beginning with black and white, then sepia, then full color during the 1940's.)

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: (singing) Oh, the little house lay in a Green Texas glade Where the trees were as coolin' As fresh lemonade Soft summer wind Had a trace of perfume And a fan was turnin’ In every room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the old ceiling fans turning, followed by several shots through the fans of the girls making love under the sheets, squeaking mattress shots, bouncing bedsprings, wi a chamber pot under the bed.

dialogues.speaker: CHORUS
dialogues.text: Twenty fans were turnin' They were turnin' Twenty fans were turnin’ In every room Fevers were a~burnin' They were burnin' And they had to have A way to cool down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Wulla Jean stands at the front door welcoming custom entering the house. We see the keys of a pianola start playing ragtime as the girls and customers break into a turn-of-the-century-style dance.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Miss Wulla Jean had a strict set of rules but she liked her ladies, as she called them, to treat her customers real good. The dancing continues, as Miss Wulla Jean makes sure her girls are behaving in a ladylike way.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: She put a pianola in the parlor to sorta help break the ice. A feller could ask a girl to dance or if he held back a little, she'd ask him. And pretty soon they'd get a little business going «~ two dollars worth. The dance ends with a couple upstairs falling into bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doughboys are coming and going.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: By the First World war, it was one of the better-known pleasure palaces in all Texas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A girl takes a cookie sheet from the kitchen oven and wal out to the garden.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: And as the girls baked cookies....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl passes by other girls knitting socks, packing cookies, writing letters and wrapping bandages for the Re Cross.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: ..and knitted socks for the guys at the front, the soldiers there bragged of the little house back home.

dialogues.speaker: MALE CHORUS
dialogues.text: (singing) It had nice watermelons All covered with vines And a vegetable garden A few slender pines White painted fence With the roses in bloom And a fan was turnin’ In every room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A girl is washing a DOUGHBOY'S privates in a hand basin.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Miss Wulla Jean insisted that each girl check her customer real good for the clap and wash him off with soap and warm water. Some of the fellas claimed that was the best part.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGHBOY
dialogues.text: Ooocoweeeeeh! The Doughboy takes off his hat and throws it off screen right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hat (now a straw boater) lands on a hat tree standing the parlor. The Doughboy (now with longer hair) is welcom by Wulla Jean at the front door. INT. CHICKEN RANCH PARLOR - NIGHT - 1920 il We pull back from a new phonograph to reveal couples danc around it -- letter-sweatered college boys and bow-tied businessmen. NARRATOR . When the war ended, Miss Wulla Jean celebrated with a new phonograph in the parlor. The girls Charleston with their customers and we intercut with the bouncing beds upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A half-dressed couple ends the dance by kicking the door closed. The music fades out and a plaintive harmonica tak over. We pan to an open window and see the dilapidated grape arbor, while wind and dust blow across the landscap

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: But prosperity blew away like a dust storm and in came the Hoover Depression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Extreme long shot of the little house looking very bleak. hot, dusty wind is blowing as an old, broken-down car mak its way down the long drive away from the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GIRL shuts the window, closing out the blowing wind. Sh turns to a young farmer, who is carrying a gunny sack.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Now, I'm sorry, honey. I gotta have my three dollars first. Miss Wulla Jean don't allow no honeyfuggin' 'til I pay my rent. The farmer picks up the sack and reaches inside.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: It wasn't always easy to come up with three dollars, especially during the hard times. The farmer pulls a chicken out of the bag and holds it up proudly for barter. The Girl sighs:

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: well, you just keep that in the bag and I'll take it out back soon as we're finished. INT. CHICKEN RANCH PARLOR ~ NIGHT - 1930'S 1s We see some girls accepting payment from three farmers wi chickens on their laps.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: And so the girls began accepting poultry in trade -- one bird, one lay....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls are feeding the chickens and as we pull back we see they have built a temporary pen full of several hundr birds.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: And that's how the place got its name -~ The Chicken Ranch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera pulls back from the new jukebox where couples jitterbugging around it to a big band sound. Miss Wulla Jean nails up a wartime portrait of F.D.R. in hallway. A bugle calls and upstairs a young customer jumps out of The girls and their guests, now dressed in World War II uniforms, dance down the steps and out the front door.  18 19 20 21 22 23 24

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Int’. CHICKEN RANCH KITCHEN ~ DAY - 1940'S In a replay of the 1914 cookie-baking sequence, a girl ta a cookie sheet from the oven and walks outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out in the victory garden, the girls, thirty years later, are still doing their patriotic bit for the boys at the front. One of the girls, sealing a letter with a lipstick kiss, turns off-screen at the sound of an approaching car

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifties-style music accompanies the arrival of a converti full of crew cut college boys. They pull up to the porch a young black woman called JEWEL waves them a welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jewel takes the boys' money and they file through the fro door joining other customers dancing rock and roll in the parlor. Miss Wulla Jean is replacing Truman's picture wit Eisenhower's. InT. A ROOM IN THE CHICKEN RANCH - NIGHT - 1950'S Three guys, careful to keep their ducktail hairdo's neatl combed, dance with their girls and somersault them into b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jewel passes a portrait of Kennedy as she walks over to Sheriff Jack Roy and his deputies leaving with two low- life characters they have just arrested. Miss Wulla Jean congratulates hin, while in the parlor customers dance to the jukebox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jewel and Miss Wulla Jean are at the “presidential Wall" taking down the picture of L.B.J. Miss Wulla Jean ages fr standing with a cane to sitting in a wheelchair while we cuts of Jewel putting up Nixon and taking him down, putti up Ford and taking him down, and then finally, at Miss Wu Jean's insistance, putting up L.B.J. to be nailed to the wall and left there permanently.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: For over three generations the little house went about its business while the town prospered, and those folks that couldn't approve of the Chicken Ranch at least decided it fell under the principle of peaceful coexistence. Miss Wulla Jean nods with satisfaction at her favorite Te president, puts down her stereopticon on the hall table a Jewel wheels her away. We push in on the stereopticon and see it contains the old sepia shot of the little house ta so many long years ago.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Course, if you grew up anywhere in Texas, you knew at an early age that they were selling something out there other than poultry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The helicopter shot. As we swoop across the countryside a up toward the little house on the hill, the music becomes wilder and picks up speed. Two cars, a farmer's pickup an an Army jeep are flying up the old dirt road to the front the house.

dialogues.speaker: CHORUS
dialogues.text: Twenty fans were turnin' They were turnin' Twenty fans were turnin' In every room Fevers were a-burnin' - They were burnin' And they had to have A way to cool down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The customers come in the door and, grabbing the girls, d the Texas Twist dance through the house.

dialogues.speaker: CHORUS
dialogues.text: Twenty fans were hummin' They were hummin' Twenty fans were hummin' In every room Customers were comin' They were comin' And they had to have A way to cool down.  27 28 29

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Customers and girls dance in the open back courtyard, whi upstairs fans are turning at a faster speed and the beds bouncing to their rhythm.

dialogues.speaker: CHORUS
dialogues.text: Twenty fans were turnin’ They were turnin' Twenty fans were turnin’ In every room. Fevers were a-burnin' They were burnin' And they had to have A way to cool down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The satisfied customers are leaving, getting into the collegiate Volkswagons and executive Pontiacs.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Y'all come back now, hear? The customers respond to Jewel's cry as if asked for an encore, and so...they turn and run into the house, nearly knocking Jewel over in the process.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music doubles in tempo and so do the fans. A montage fun filled sexual shenanigans, cutting from the dancing i the parlor to the bouncing beds upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: CHORUS
dialogues.text: Twenty fans were turnin' They were turnin' Twenty fans were turnin' in every room Fevers were a-burnin' They were burnin' And they had to have A way to cool down. Twenty fans were hummin’ They were hummin' Twenty fans were hummin' In every room. Customers were comin' They were comin' And they had to have A way to cool down.  30 31 32 33 34

dialogues.speaker: CHICKEN RANCH
dialogues.text: A cowboy, still wearing his hat in bed, is ecstatically coming to a climax.

dialogues.speaker: CHICKEN RANCH
dialogues.text: His shadow is silhouetted on the window shade and we hear his excited Voice.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: I'm comin'! I'm comin'! Thank you. Thank you, Jesus. We pan off the window up to the metal rooster weather van on the roof and as horizon, the names the morning sun breaks across the of our stars flash across the screen.... Burt Reynolds... Dolly Parton... The Best

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Whorehouse in Texas!

dialogues.speaker: SHOTS OF TEXAS
dialogues.text: The rest of the Main Title Credits play over beautiful vistas of the East Texas countryside while the orchestra gives a zippy taste of some of the songs to come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pan down from the sky, past the Texas flag and take a full shot of the Gilbert town square.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: When Sheriff Jack Roy Wallace retired, about ten years ago now, Deputy Ed Earl Dodd was elected to the job. Everybody likes Ed Earl..;.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mayor, RUFUS P. potential customer tires. POINDEXTER, is showing a car to a while the customer's wife kicks the

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The mayor, Rufus P. Poindexter, leans on him to keep the town running peacefully....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDSEL MACKEY is pulling the proof pages off the presses.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Edsel Mackey, the editor of the Gilbert Gazette, has supported Ed Earl in every Ccampaign....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DULCIE MAE, a not unattractive widow in her early forties is supervising the breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: And over at the cafe, the owner, Miss Dulcie Mae...well she is kind of prejudiced cause everyone knows she's been stuck on Ed Earl for years, ever since her husband passed away. She has a fine son, Billy, and.... Dulcie Mae is pouring coffee and she looks off at someone shouting in the town square. The customers look off, too.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Humm...What's that commotion out there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THREE NESTERS playing dominoes in the gazebo turn their heads and look off as a hysterical MODENE ENNIS, sporting tight new permanent hairdo, runs across the street and up the steps of the courthouse.

dialogues.speaker: MODENE
dialogues.text: Dammit! Dammit!

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Oh, it's that town troublemaker, Modene Ennis, heading up to Ed Earl's office to give him a hard time again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Modene dashes down the corridor, screaming.

dialogues.speaker: MODENE
dialogues.text: Ed Earl! Ed Earl! She walks through the swinging door, past a startled RITA CROWELL, Ed Earl's gray-haired secretary.

dialogues.speaker: MODENE
dialogues.text: Morning, Rita. DEPUTY FRED WILKINS is coming out of Ed Earl's office. He is swept back inside by the force of Modene's entrance.

dialogues.speaker: MODENE
dialogues.text: Morning, Deputy Fred. She plants herself in front of the sheriff's desk, where ED EARL, leaning back in his chair, is whittling chains f a block of wood. Behind his desk hang portraits of all ni County Sheriffs ending with Jack Roy Wallace and Ed Earl Dodd.

dialogues.speaker: MODENE
dialogues.text: Ed Earl, now listen up. You've got yourself a problem. Ed Earl looks up and tips his hat back on his head.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Morning, Miss Modene.

dialogues.speaker: MODENE
dialogues.text: It just ain't right for Tucker Faylin to keep on doing this. I've talked to him. I've talked to you. There is a law in this county, Sheriff, and it's up to you to see that it's carried out. Ed Earl stands up and grabs his gun and holster.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: I'll take care of it.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY FRED
dialogues.text: Do you want me to bring the rifle?

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Put it down, Fred. I've handled this situation before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mule is standing in front of Miss Modene's car, with hi behind sitting on the highly-polished hood. A few townspeople have gathered around to look at the bizarre sight. Ed Earl, with his guns strapped on, looking like he's goi out to meet Billy the Kid, walks across the street from t Courthouse. Behind him are Rita and Deputy Fred; while Miss Modene, keeping up beside him, continues to babble.

dialogues.speaker: MODENE
dialogues.text: I came out of the beauty shop and there he was, standing right in front of my car. I tried to back up, but I couldn't, so I went forward slowly, figuring that he'd move, but he just buckled up his back legs and sat right down on my hood. The group stops as Modene points at her predicament. Ed Earl is not fazed at all. He walks up to the mule and addresses him, man to man.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Mornin', mule. I'm Sheriff Ed Earl Dodd and I've got a request here for you to, pardon the expression, move your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MANSEL, the barber, is giving C.J. VERNON, the insurance salesman, his morning shave. C.J. looks out the window. C.J. What's going on out there?

dialogues.speaker: MANSEL
dialogues.text: Ed Earl's talking to that jackass again. C.J. You mean the mule or Miss Modene? They both laugh and settle back. EXT. BEAUTY SHOP - DAY 4i Ed Earl continues addressing the mule.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry you're taking it this way. I don't want to lose my _ temper because, as folks will tell you, that can be real trouble.

dialogues.speaker: MODENE
dialogues.text: Sheriff, you got to get him off there. Where's Tucker Faylin?

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY FRED
dialogues.text: Why don't you give him a tug?

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Shut up, Fred. Now, listen, mule. I don't want to get physical with you. I want to be real polite. So, I'm asking you for the last time...Move! The mule stares back at him and is singularly unimpressed Ed Earl gives up.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Okay. If that's your decision. He takes a cheroot from his breast pocket and puts it in mouth. He strikes a match on his belt buckle and lights t cigar. Modene is very agitated at Ed Earl's calm and his lack of progress.

dialogues.speaker: MODENE
dialogues.text: What are you going to do, Sheriff? I'm expected back home. Ed Earl walks out of frame. A quick cut of the mule's tai being lifted off the hood. The mule looks over his should to see what's happening.

dialogues.speaker: MODENE
dialogues.text: Sheriff, are you listening to me? LOUISE MAPLES, an elderly lady of the town and a staunch supporter of Ed Earl, butts in.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Hush, Modene. The Sheriff knows what he's doing.

dialogues.speaker: MODENE
dialogues.text: Don't hush me, Louise. I've spent fifteen dollars on this permanent and I'm so upset it's beginning to lose it's shape. The sudden loud whinny of the mule startles them both. Deputy Fred and Rita back up in fright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mansel and C.J. look out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three nesters look up from their game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long shot of the mule as it gallops wildly across the t square.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dulcie Mae glances up from the counter as Ed Earl enters sits down.

dialogues.speaker: DULCIE MAE
dialogues.text: Morning, Ed Earl.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Morning, Dulcie. She begins to pour him a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: DULCIE MAE
dialogues.text: I heard all that noise out there. How did you get that animal to move?

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Well, Dulcie Mae, the way to handle an animal is like my daddy used to tell me. He used to say....

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: There's a crash from the kitchen and the COOK comes runni in.

dialogues.speaker: . COOK
dialogues.text: You won't believe what I saw.

dialogues.speaker: DULCIE MAE
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: I just saw a mule run by my window blowing cigar smoke out of his ass. Dulcie Mae looks at Ed Earl. He picks up his coffee.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: That's what my daddy told me. Dulcie Mae laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun goes down over a long shot of the Chicken Ranch.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Just about the time Ed Earl took over his job as Sheriff, Miss Wulla Jean passed away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jewel, now more mature, is greeting customers at the fron door and taking their money. Miss Wulla Jean's black crep draped portrait hangs on the wall and couples are still dancing to the old jukebox in the front parlor.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: She bequeathed her place in her will to her favorite working girl, Mona Stangley, who, you might say, had worked her way up from the bottom. ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and, from a low angle, we see a glamorous pair of legs walk along the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: No one knew much about her, where she came from or why, but they did know she ran the same tight ship and carried on the same tradition of quality. 45 46 47 48  49

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow the woman until she turns at the top landing. Customers at the front door turn their heads and look up. MONA STANGLEY, glamorously gowned, smiles a welcome and begins walking down the stairs. Miss Mona

dialogues.text: (singing) It's just a little old Bitty pissant country place Ain't nothin' much to see No drinking allowed We get a nice quiet crowd Plain as it can be. It's just a piddly squattin' ole Time country place Ain't nothin' too high-toned Jes' lots of good will And maybe one small thrill But there's nothing dirty goin' on!

dialogues.text: It's just a piddly squattin' Old time country place Nothin' too high-toned Jes' lots of good will And maybe one small thrill But there's nothin' dirty goin' on!

dialogues.text: All the girls, in their nighties and bathrobes, are down breakfast, but Jewel seated at the big table. The Cook has a helper, is in charge of serving.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Keep your language clean, girls Keep your bedrooms neat Don't hang around the town cafe Or say 'hi' on the street. Mind your P's and Q's And manners And you don't need no other tools ‘Cause every girl who lives here knows My special no-no rules.

dialogues.text: Yeah, every girl who lives here knows Miss Mona's no-no rules.

dialogues.text: Ruby Rae, start ‘em.

dialogues.text: And it don't make money. Beatrice....

dialogues.text: Eloise, honey....

dialogues.speaker: MONA

dialogues.text: Brands belong on cattle And that ain't what we're Sellin' at Miss Mona's.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Do you catch my drift? I pay the food and the rent And the utilities You keep your mind on your work Responsibilities Don't let your mouth overload your Capabilities And we can get along...Dawn....

dialogues.speaker: MONA AND GIRLS
dialogues.text: Better get here double quick!

dialogues.text: It's the afternoon free time and while the girls lounge around outside in their day wear, Miss Mona continues singing.

dialogues.text: A rooster standing on a fence post crows to greet the ris sun. Last night's guests come straggling out, feeling spe but happy. The girls yawn and stretch and wave good-bye from the porch or the upstairs windows. Everybody looks very contented.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: And so the Chicken Ranch continued to live in peace with the town and the folks there took secret pride in the oldest established, permanently operating, non-floating whorehouse in Texas...that is, until about a year ago last Thanksgiving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a cloud of dust, Ed Earl speeds his sheriff's car down country road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Earl looks very agitated as if he were chasing a crimi He glances at his watch and steps on the gas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita, seated at her desk, has finished writing out a rece

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I can't tell you how thrilled we are with this contribution, Miss Mona. Here's your receipt. She hands the receipt to Mona, who is standing at the cou in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Thank you, Rita.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Those kids will be so excited. And the Mayor, too. Why, the town council will probably vote you another plaque.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: I hope not, Rita. I've gota closet full of them now. Dulcie Mae steps in from the corridor and stops when she sees Mona.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Hello, Dulcie Mae. You know Miss Mona.

dialogues.speaker: DULCIE MAE
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. We've met. Mornin’.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: How are you?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Isn't this wonderful. Miss Mona has capped the goal for the Little League Fund Campaign.

dialogues.speaker: DULCIE MAE
dialogues.text: How nice. On behalf of my son and his teammates, I'd like to thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Tell them I'll be well repaid when they take the championship this year. Good-bye, Rita. Mona starts for the door.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry the Sheriff wasn't here to thank you. He drove over to Meritsville. He'll be gone all afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Well, tell him i said hi. (to Dulcie) "Bye.

dialogues.speaker: DULCIE MAE
dialogues.text: ‘Bye.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: 'Bye. Mona leaves.  60 61 62 63

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Earl continues racing across the countryside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mona is getting into her car as Deputy Fred drives up.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY FRED
dialogues.text: Hello, Miss Mona. Nice to see you.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Hello, Deputy Fred. You keeping an eye on my place at night?

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY FRED
dialogues.text: Sure are. The Sheriff's real particular about the security out there.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Well, some night when you're not on duty you drop on by. I'm sure the girls would like to show their appreciation.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY FRED
dialogues.text: Oh, Miss Mona, shucks. You know I'm a married man.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Now, Fred, you think the cows don't appreciate the time off when the bull goes on over to the next pasture?

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY FRED
dialogues.text: (blushing) Oh, Miss Mona. Mona laughs and drives out of town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A closeup of Ed Earl as he continues driving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His Sheriff's car speeds past camera.  64 65 66

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Earl turns his car off the highway and drives up to th front porch of a house. He gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Earl strides across the living room to the bedroom, se a jacket flung over a chair, fingers it for a moment, smi to himself, then flings open the bedroom door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Earl stops in the doorway and his face falls at what h sees.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Dammit! We cut and see a figure lying in bed in the darkened room The lights turn on. Mona is lying in his bed with a sheet pulled up coyly to her chin. She smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: You've gotten into bed already.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: I've told you a hundred times, watching you undress is the best part.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: The best part?

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Well, maybe not the best part, but certainly in the top two.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Well then, Ed Earl.... She throws off the sheet and we see that she's lying in b fully clothed. Ed Earl laughs.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: I'm glad I was late.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Me too. He starts toward the bed, but she bounces out and picks u package from her tote bag.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Now, just hold it for a second. I've got a surprise for you. I picked up a package this morning from the post office. It's the latest thing from Frederick's of Hollywood. She holds up a black shorty negligee. He isn't very impressed.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Not much to it.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: I think I can fill it out. She goes into the bathroom. He laughs and shouts after he

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: I'll bet you can. He quickly undoes his tie and takes off his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: I swear to God, Mona, there ain't a woman in the world that can get me as excited as you can. MONA (v.o.) Even after all these years we been meeting like this?

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Every year with you, darlin', is like a minute of sheer happiness. MONA (v.0.) That's very sweet, Ed Earl.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Well, you bring out the romantic in me.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He undoes his belt and drops his pants. He looks up as Mo appears in the doorway. She looks stunning in her black negligee.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Woweeee! That was quick.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: I've had a lot of practice getting in and out of my clothes. What do you think? She models it for him.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Hot damn, Mona, it makes me feel real sexy.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: You don't look very sexy.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: (taken aback) What do you mean? I look like I always look.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: That's the problem. It's those damn boxer shorts. I can't stand the look of those droopy white drawers.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: These? What's the matter with them? I always wear boxer shorts. I've worn them for years.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: They look it.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: This is a brand new pair. And what do you mean I don't look sexy? People have always said I look sexy. They say I have a sexy quality.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: You do, but those boxer shorts don't. Now, look here. This is what I ordered expressly for you.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She takes a pair of black jockey shorts from her tote bag He shuffles over to her with his pants still around his b and takes a look at them.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Looks like a Japanese sling shot.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: It's a pair of jockey shorts with little silver snaps on the side.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: I'm not getting into those. They'd kill me.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: They cost me twenty dollars, plus postage, Ed Earl, and I want you to wear them.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Twenty dollars for that little thing? You got screwed.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Come on, Ed Earl.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: I'm not putting them on.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: If they look half as good as I think they will, you won't have to keep them on for long.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Mona, I'm not going to wear that thing. They're ridiculous. They're embarassing.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: They're sexy.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: I said 'no' and that's the end of it.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Okay, then I'm getting dressed.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Okay, I'11 put them on.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He grabs them and, still shuffling, makes his way into th bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: (muttering) Damn. They'll be like putting two bowling balls in a marble sack. Mona laughs and takes the phone off the hook. She goes to closet and brings out a pillow.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: I saw Dulcie Mae in town today. Ed Earl talks from the bathroom. ED EARL (v.o0.) Oh, yeah?

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: I_ expect you're going out to her place for Thanksgiving dinner? ED EARL (v.0.) Don't I always?

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Well, you better start checking that turkey, 'cause there's a hook inside that's gonna land you right over at the wedding chapel. ED EARL (v.0o.) Not me, Mona. I don't believe in that stuff. It don't work out.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Amen to that. Ed Earl sticks his head out around the door.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Ready?

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: I'm always ready.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Like a flash, Ed Earl runs out of the bathroom across the room, jumps into bed and pulls the sheet up to his chin. Mona laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Oh, Ed Earl. Is that it?

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Yeah. How was it?

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: But I hardly saw them.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: That's too bad, because I ain't going to parade around this room like some damn model.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Come on, Ed Earl. Do it for me.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: I just want to take a look at them.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: No. Mona lifts up the bottom of the sheet.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Come on, just a little peek.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: No. She puts her hand under the sheet. Ed Earl jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Mona! Mona withdraws her hand and holds up the shorts in triump

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: That's what the little silver snaps are for.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: (laughing) Come on over here and let me put a lip-lock on you. Ooops! Wait! I've gotta brush my teeth. He grabs the bedspread, wraps it around himself and hobbl into the bathroom. Mona laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Oh, Ed Earl, I like a lot of things, but these afternoons with you have got to top the list.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Sing it to me, honey.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: (singing) I like fancy frilly things High-heeled shoes and diamond rings Ragtime bands and western swing And sneakin' around with you.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: (singing) I like beer and rodeos Detective books and dominoes Football games and Cheerios And sneakin' around with you.

dialogues.speaker: TOGETHER
dialogues.text: Sneakin' around with you Goin' a round or two Doin’ what lovers do Whenever we're sneaking around.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: I like lots of cash on hand And dirty jokes about the Fuller Brush Man.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: I like stuff I understand Like sneakin' around with you.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: I like a thrill that has no strings.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Friendship that don't ever change.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: And laughter from the joy of things.

dialogues.speaker: TOGETHER
dialogues.text: And sneakin' around with you We're just sneakin' around We're not chained and bound Sharin' the ups and downs Of lovers sneakin' around.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Oh, I like drive-in picture shows Kissin' long and lovin' slow.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: The secret places lovers go Whenever they're sneakin' around I like the crazy things we try.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: And the sexy things we fantasize.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: And makin' out in broad daylight.

dialogues.speaker: TOGETHER
dialogues.text: Sneakin' around with you Sneakin' around with you Keepin' it all brand new Gettin' the best of you Whenever we're sneakin' around.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Sneakin' around that's all.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: I’m gonna lay down the law.

dialogues.speaker: TOGETHER
dialogues.text: Watchin' the rise and fall Of lovers sneakin' around.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: We're just sneakin' around.

dialogues.speaker: TOGETHER
dialogues.text: Wetre just sneakin'.... The song ends with them sitting on the edge of the bed ju about to kiss. But this kiss is interrupted by a sudden loud knocking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deputy Fred is knocking at the front door.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY FRED
dialogues.text: Sheriff. Sheriff. INT. ED EARL'S BEDROOM - DAY — 68 Ed Earl and Mona haven't moved. They listen.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: It's Deputy Fred. What the hell does he want?

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: I don't know. I think you better go find out.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Okay. Hold that position. I'11 be right back. He leaves her sitting on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deputy Fred is continuing to knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY FRED
dialogues.text: Sheriff! It's me, Deputy Fred. The door opens and Ed Earl stands in the doorway, wearing nothing but the bedspread. .

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: This better be important.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY FRED
dialogues.text: Well, I think it is. I saw your car from the highway and I figured your phone must be out because what are you wearing that for?

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: I'm taking a shower.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY FRED
dialogues.text: Oh. I always take mine in the morning. I read in the Reader's Digest about....

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: I don't care. What the hell do you want?

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY FRED
dialogues.text: It's the Mayor. He's real anxious to speak to you. Rita's been calling all over the county for you. He wants a meeting right away.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Can't it wait?

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY FRED
dialogues.text: You mean until after you take a shower?

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Go radio them that I'll be back when I get there. Nothing's that important it can't wait until this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Earl shuts the door and walks back into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Earl enters, looks around and sees Mona's negligee fol neatly by the side of the bed. He picks it up for a minut then hears a car start off outside. He throws down the negligee and starts for the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Earl crosses the living room and opens the front door.  73 74

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Earl steps out on the porch and looks. in the driveway Deputy Fred ig talking to Mona. She drives off and he wav good-bye. Chuckling to himself, Deputy Fred walks over to the porch.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY FRED
dialogues.text: Ain't that funny. All this time, Misa Mona was at the back, knocking on the screen door. She said she's in a hurry but just dropped by to give you this. He hands Ed Earl the pair of black jockey shorts with the little silver snaps. Ed Earl takes it and holds it up, shaking his head. Deputy Fred explains.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY FRED
dialogues.text: It's a Japanese slingshot. Ed Earl shoots him a look, then turns and goes back insid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mayor and C.J. have been anxiously waiting for the Sheriff. Ed Earl enters, followed by Deputy Fred, and mak his way over to his desk.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Okay, Rufus, what's on your mind?

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Something that could have serious implications to the health of this town. Tell ‘im, C.J., just like you told me. c.J. Well, Sheriff, I have a friend who works at a TV station in Houston and he's tipped me off that Melvin P. Thorpe is planning to do an expose on the Chicken Ranch.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Melvin P. Thorpe. He's that crazy consumer advocate. Has that report on the late night news.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY FRED
dialogues.text: He's got a new show now. Half hour. Once a week. The Watchdog Report. It's on tonight.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: well, I don't think he can say anything about the Chicken Ranch on TV. It's supposed to be a family mediun.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: But he's a sensationalist, Ed Earl. He shows up with his TV camera anytime a consumer has a complaint. He's a menace to the business community.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY FRED
dialogues.text: He's the fella who put the peanuts back in the chocolate bar.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY FRED
dialogues.text: He made the makers of the Peanut Delight candy bar admit they put less peanuts in each bar than they advertise and got them to change their ways.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Sounds like a pretty tough customer.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY FRED
dialogues.text: He has a lot of influence out there.

dialogues.speaker: . MAYOR
dialogues.text: And if he starts bringing his cameras out to the Chicken Ranch....

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Calm down, Rufus. Let me make a few phone calls. I've got a little influence out there myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MANAGER of KPTZ, Channel 4, is talking to Ed Earl on phone.

dialogues.speaker: TV STATION MANAGER
dialogues.text: It's no use talking to ma, Sheriff. Melvin P. Thorpe is now the biggest attraction at this station. High ratings, lots of letters. He doesn't listen to anybody. Hell, he wants to go national. He wants to be watchdog for the whole U.S. of A.  76 77 78

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHERIFF CHAPMAN of Houston, a friend of Ed Earl's, is tal to him on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: I'd like to help you, Ed Earl, but just like you don't want to mess with the Chicken Ranch, I don't want to ruffle the feathers of this bird. He's getting to be a regular Texas attraction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SENATOR CHARLES WINGWOOD, an undistinguished blowhard legistator, is on the phone with Ed Earl.

dialogues.speaker: . SENATOR
dialogues.text: Now wait a minute, Ed Earl. I'd tread easy on this one. Those TV boys can be mighty powerful -- and mighty useful, if you get my meaning. The SENATOR'S AIDE interrupts.

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: Senator, a quorum call.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR
dialogues.text: Sorry, I've got to go. Damn food stamps again. But let me give you a word of advice from one elected official to another -- be careful of the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Earl hangs up in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: What the hell's going on? This Melvin P. Thorpe character has everybody bamboozled. Deputy Fred, you hold down the fort.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Where you goin'?

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: I'm driving up to Houston to take care of that little peckerwood myself. Ed Earl grabs his hat and stalks out.  79 80 81

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mona drives up to the Chicken Ranch and parks her car aro back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mona comes in the back door and walks through the kitchen Jewel stops her at the bottom of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Hi, Miss Mona.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Hello, Jewel. How'd everything go this afternoon?

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: It's been quiet. A couple Army boys from Fort Hood. And right now the Coca-Cola man is making a delivery upstairs. Oh, and there's a girl wants to see you in the parlor.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: We ain't hiring.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: That's what I told her, but she is persistent. I think you should see her.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mona walks into the parlor. A young straggly haired count girl with a cardboard suitcase stands up as she enters an gives Mona a very pretty, somewhat nervous smile. We get know her later as SHY.

dialogues.speaker: SHY
dialogues.text: Hello. Miss Mona?

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: SHY
dialogues.text: My name's Anna Merle Seltzer.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They sit. 39 81

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Well, sit down, Anna Merle.

dialogues.speaker: SHY
dialogues.text: I want a job here.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: I'm kinda choosey about who lives in my house. Who told you about it?

dialogues.speaker: SHY
dialogues.text: Well, I met a girl in Galveston....

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Ever have a run-in with the law?

dialogues.speaker: SHY
dialogues.text: No, ma'am. And I don't want to. That's why I'd like to work in a respectable place.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: How much experience have you had?

dialogues.speaker: SHY
dialogues.text: You mean professional?

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: For money, honey.

dialogues.speaker: SHY
dialogues.text: About a year.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: On the streets?

dialogues.speaker: SHY
dialogues.text: No, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: For a pimp?

dialogues.speaker: SHY
dialogues.text: No, ma‘am.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Motel, hotel, telephone, van?

dialogues.speaker: SHY
dialogues.text: I, uh...I.... Shy trails off. She is obviously lying. Mona drops the businesswoman manner and speaks softly.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: What are you doin' here, honey? Shy is near tears. She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: I think maybe you better just head on back home.

dialogues.speaker: SHY
dialogues.text: I'm broke.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Well, I could lend you fifty dollars. Course you'd have to pay me back someday.

dialogues.speaker: SHY
dialogues.text: It ain't that, ma'am. I got nowheres to go home to.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Boyfriend treat you bad?

dialogues.speaker: SHY
dialogues.text: No, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Folks run you off?

dialogues.speaker: SHY
dialogues.text: No, but I ain't never goin' back there. She glares straight at Mona and we see a toughness for th first time.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Did your daddy get sweet on you, honey? Shy lowers her eyes. She can't answer, but we know it's true.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Well, that ain't the first time it's happened to a girl, it ain't gonna be the last. Maybe I can get you a job downtown at the five and dime.

dialogues.speaker: SHY
dialogues.text: No. I don't want no sales job! I done thought about this. I'm gonna stay right here...I mean, if you'll let me.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Ordinarily I put girls like you on the next Greyhound, but a smile don't cost nothin' and you came in with one. Ain't nothin' worse for business than girls sittin' around the parlor with long faces.

dialogues.speaker: SHY
dialogues.text: Can I stay, then?

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Well, I'm gonna try you out for a while. {shouting out) Jewel...come on in here. {to Shy) We've got to get you some new clothes and do something about that hair. I'll have one of the girls take you to a beauty shop tomorrow. There are three in town and I like to rotate my business among then. They appreciate that and treat us real nice.... Shy suddenly embraces Mona and sobs uncontrollably. Mona at first surprised, then holds her and tries to comfort h

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Come on, now, honey. You're gonna mess up my outfit. But Shy is like a puppy that's been saved from the pound. She keeps crying and Mona finds herself being very moved.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Oh, Lord, girl. You got me on the edge of crying. And I've done retired from it. Come on, now. Get a hold on. You'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jewel enters and stands in the doorway. Shy stops crying and Mona wipes away Shy's tears.

dialogues.speaker: SHY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Miss Mona.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: That's all right, honey. I know how you feel. (singing) Bein' born was the worst and the first Mistake I ever made The doctor didn't spank me He just slapped me in the face And the cup of love was always quenchin' Someone else's thirst Leaving me to swallow The bitter taste of hurt. ‘Cause I was raised an orphan Never wanted as a kid Until the year I turned thirteen Then everybody did — Strangers passed me back and forth Men just took me as they pleased And others had a Cinderella slave To cook and clean and weave. Though the deck is stacked against you Win or lose you have to play The hand that life has dealt you And it's a gamble either way. On a dusty road at fifteen In a yellow cotton dress With the desert sun like an angry dragon Breathin' down my neck And the dry cracked plains that made me think Of a prehistoric time Should I fear what lay before me Less than what I'd left behind. A fifteen year old girl don't have No trouble hitchin' rides But sometimes when you're ridin' free You'll pay the highest price On back roads, and in backseats And in cheap highway motels But what's a few more strangers In a life of nothin' else.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MONA (Cont'd) (singing) Though the deck is stacked against you Win or lose you have to play The hand that life has dealt you And it's a gamble either way. Sixteen found me cryin! Underneath a scarlet light On the doorstep of a stranger On a cold and rainy night When I walked into the parlor here The pieces seemed to fit I was good at pleasin' strangers So I made the most of it. Either way it's all a gamble So view the stakes and know the odds Lay your cards upon the table Do your dealin' from the top. Though the deck is stacked against you Win or lose you have to play The hand that life has dealt you And it's a gamble either way (spoken) Yeah, it's a gamble either way. Jewel, who has been listening through the song, glances o at Mona. A look of recognition passes between them. Shy looks up at Jewel.

dialogues.speaker: SHY
dialogues.text: Miss Mona's gonna let me stay.

dialogues.speaker: SEWEL
dialogues.text: That's wonderful, child, but after talking to you this afternoon it don't surprise me none. Mona smiles at Jewel and walks out to the hallway to beck to the girls passing by.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Girls, come on in here. Ginger and Ruby Rae enter. Mona introduces them to Shy.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Girls, this is Anna Merle Seltzer. Goodness, that's a mouthful. We've got to do something about that. Even at our reduced rates, that name's a tough sell.

dialogues.speaker: SHY
dialogues.text: Well, I was thinking of changing it to Dawn.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Hmmm. I already got me a Dawn. I'm just gonna call you Shy 'til I can think of something better. This is Ginger and Ruby Rae.

dialogues.speaker: GINGER
dialogues.text: Howdy.

dialogues.speaker: RUBY RAE
dialogues.text: Hello, honey.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Take Shy upstairs and show her around. She'll be boarding with us for a while.

dialogues.speaker: SHY
dialogues.text: Thanks, Miss Mona.

dialogues.speaker: GINGER
dialogues.text: Well, that's good news. We can sure use the help with all them college boys coming over here Thanksgiving night.

dialogues.speaker: SHY
dialogues.text: College boys?

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Yeah. The winning seniors from the Texas Aggie/Texas University football game get treated to a night here on Thanksgiving.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: By their Alumni Association.

dialogues.speaker: RUBY RAE
dialogues.text: It's a tradition. Been going on for years.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: You see, honey, the Chicken Ranch is a Texas institution and I aim to keep it that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pan down from a helicopter shot of the Houston skyline and zero into the building that houses Channel 4.  83 84

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Earl is following a Page down the aisle of the TV stud backstage. The Page shows him Melvin's dressing room and exits. Ed Earl knocks on the door. MELVIN (v.o) Come in. Ed Earl enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MELVIN P. THORPE is sitting in his white T-shirt and American flag boxer shorts while he puts the finishing touches to the straightening of his silver-haired wig. Ed Earl is a little surprised.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Mister Thorpe? Melvin looks up in the mirror, sees him and jumps up with smile.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: I know you.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: You do?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Aren't you Sheriff Ed Earl Doda from over in Lanville County?

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: That's right, how did you....

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Well, this is surely my pleasure... (shaking hands enthusiastically) My honor. What brings you up here to Houston? Please, sit down. (waves to the couch) Anywhere over there. I'm just getting dressed. I've got the show tonight and I'm running a bit behind time. Ed Earl sits on the couch and Melvin returns to dressing.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 84
dialogues.text: During the following dialogue, Ed Earl watches him put on his corset, jock pad, shoulder pads, red, white and blue suit and tie, pearl-handled revolvers in silver-studded holsters, handcuffs and white cowboy boots.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Well, it's the show I want to talk to you about, Mister Thorpe.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Melvin.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Melvin....

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: You watch the show, Ed?

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Well, I....

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Last week was the best rating we ever had. The City Planning Commissioner driving a city car while he was on vacation! We broke a thirty share. And it's affecting my pieces on the late night news. Up! Up! Up! They love my little report.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: I've heard you're very popular.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: The power of television -- of public exposure -- is so great it scares me. I swear I could get the Mayor's own children to throw rocks at him. Which show did you like best?

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Well, I...I thought the peanuts in the chocolate bar....

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: One of my favorites! Three score means sixty, like the Bible says. So, if it says sixty nuts on the

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MELVIN (Cont'd) wrapper, I want to count sixty nuts inside. Right?.-.And I'm talking whole nuts, not half nuts or nut bits or nut chips. We're talking a full nut!

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: I can see that.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Thank God we still live in a society where anything that's phony or dishonest can't stand the light of day. He puts on his shirt over his padded shoulders and gets o pad caught. Ed@ Earl points it out.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Your pad there....

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Oh, thanks...Yes, most corporations involved in false advertising will just laugh at a fifty dollar fine, but if you show up with a TV camera and give tem bad publicity, they shape up faster than goose shit through a tin horn.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: It's that bad publicity that I want to talk to you about. Sometimes it can hurt people. Like this report I hear you're planning on the Chicken Ranch. That place has been operating peacefully for a long time. Hell, I wouldn't be surprised if your granddaddy took your daddy out there to learn about the birds and the bees.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: I'm from New Jersey.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: I moved to Houston six years ago.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: The point I want to make is every schoolboy in the state knows about it, most politicians have slept there, and the town, the Mayor and the folks who elected me want to keep things the way they are.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: What is your interest in this whorehouse, Sheriff?

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Well, my deputies patrol out there, stop fights before they start. The girls' police records are checked, so are their health cards. And as for getting information that helps us solve crimes, why the Chicken Ranch is a better intelligence- gathering operation than all those FBI flyers they keep mailing me.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: You know, Sheriff, it just struck me. We're in the same profession.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Law enforcement. I'm out there fighting for the rights of the public just like you. We're both of us protecting the people -+ you in the old way; me in the new.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: The new?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Television! I'm the electronic bounty hunter. I use a camera; you use a gun. Ed Earl is not impressed with this comparison. He begings talking tough.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Melvin, all I want to say is you'd be doing everybody a big favor if

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ED EARL (Cont'd) you'd drop this whole thing. The girls perform a wanted service and right or wrong....

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Right or wrong don't interest me. I'm no moralizer. I leave all that to the preacher. Ed Earl is a bit: taken back by this admission and a litt confused. - Lae

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Really? Well, I'm glad to hear - that. The Mayor was feeling that you'd stir up a lot of unnecessary publicity.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Unnecessary publicity! He's got me all wrong. I'm not one of those sensation mongers out for their own egos. He finishes dressing and stands looking at himself in fro of the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: (pause) It's...different.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: I designed it myself. No, you tell your Mayor he's got nothing to fear from me on that score.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Really? Well, he'll be happy to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: I'm a lawman. That's my interest. The law! Right, pardner. He grabs Ed Earl's hand and shakes it. Ed Earl has still not gotten a clear bead on this eccentric character, but figures he's got what he came for.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Come on, we've got to get out of here. That's my cue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hurry down the hall to the studio's stage.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Listen, I'd like to do an interview with you.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Well, I don't think I'm the type.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Nonsense. You are exactly what the public wants to see. Trust me. Look, we'll talk about it after the show. I want you to be my guest. This is the sponsor's booth. Just sit in there and make yourself comfortable. Bourbon, beer, anything you want.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Not at all. I admire you, Sheriff. You're my kind of cowboy. See ya. He leaves and Ed Earl, not too sure of himself and thinki he needs a drink, goes into the booth and sits down. He begins lighting a cheroot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOGETTES, Melvin's chorus of four male and four femal singers, have already begun their opening introduction.

dialogues.speaker: DOGETTES
dialogues.text: (singing) Watchdog will get you If you don't watch out Watchdog sees and watchdog knows

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 86
dialogues.text: DOGETTES (Cont'd) Watchdog keeps us on our toes Watchdog assures you That the law's the law No exceptions to the rule Watchdog ain't no fool. A flustered stage manager is giving signals to Melvin and the cameras.

dialogues.speaker: DOGETTES
dialogues.text: Watchdog protects you He's out on the prowl Guards and checks the best he can watchdog is a fighting man Watchdog will throw his Beam of light around If some folks don't tow the line Watchdog's light will shine.

dialogues.speaker: A DOGETTE
dialogues.text: (speaking) And now, The Watchdog Man himself. The eyes and ears of Texas, Melvin P. Thorpe! Melvin steps out on the stage and stands before a great m of Texas. The Dogettes cheer and the audience wildly applauds as an "Applause" sign flashes.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Thank you, fellow Texans, and welcome to the Watchdog Report with yours truly Melvin P. Thorpe keeping an eye on what's going on in this beautiful state of ours.

dialogues.speaker: DOGETTES
dialogues.text: (singing) Shine, Shine, Shine Shine, Shine, Shine Shine, Shine, Shine.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: This week's spotlight will shine on the shameful situation that has been allowed to exist for close to a hundred years. I'm talking about the Chicken Ranch, my friends. The proprietor of this innocent-looking ranch house is a woman known only

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 52 CONTINUED - 2 a6 MELVIN (Cont'd) as ‘Miss Mona' and the man who turns his back on her illegal operation is Sheriff Ed Earl Dodd. Ed Earl, sitting behind the glass, stares in open-mouthed horror at the mention of his name.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Did I say ‘illegal?’ Yes, I did! Now, I know this is TV, so I'll try to be as delicate as I can, but, isn't this the age of tellin' it like it is?

dialogues.speaker: DOGETTES
dialogues.text: Amen! Amen! Hallelujah!

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Well, then let's get this thing out in the open! Here goes, and may God forgive me! (pause) Texas...has a whorehouse in it!

dialogues.speaker: DOGETTES
dialogues.text: (singing) Lord have mercy on our souls!

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: (singing) Texas has a whorehouse in it!

dialogues.speaker: DOGETTES
dialogues.text: (singing) Lord have mercy on our souls!

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: I'll expose the facts Although it fills me with disgust. Please excuse the filthy, dark details And carnal lust.

dialogues.speaker: DOGETTES
dialogues.text: Filthy, dark details and carnal lust!

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Dancin' goin' on inside it Don't you see they've gone plumb wild I inquired no one denied it Now I think I'm getting riled

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MELVIN (Cont'd) Bodies close together Arms and legs all rearranged And the Sheriff does not close it down That's very strange! Melvin points over to the sponsor's booth as the audience in unison, turns to look at Ed Earl.

dialogues.speaker: AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: (singing) Does not close it down That's very strange!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Earl is taken aback at the sudden attention. He looks out at the audience and then up at the monitors where the show is being broadcast across Texas.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: We go to quick cuts of TV sets throughout the studio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick cuts of families watching TV. A series of heads turning. A family at the dinner table staring at the TV with their forks halfway to their mouths. A father puts down his newspaper. A grandmother chokes. A grandfather chuckles. A mother claps her hands over her daughter's ea MELVIN (v.0.) Mean-eyed, juiced up, brilliantined honky-tonk cowboys! DOGETTES (v.o.) Oh, no!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old folks stop rocking. Hearing aids are turned up. Domin games stop. MELVIN (v.o.) Mixin' with green-eyed, thin-lipped hard-as-nails, peroxide blondes!  91 92 93 94 95

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nurse drops a glass of medicine. A patient pites his spoon. An intern lets go a trolley. DOGETIES (v.0.) oh, no!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A holdup man and his victim stop in midrobbery to look at the Tv set. MELVIN (v.0o-) Not to mention some types that you'd never guess would venture near...-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Customers stare in surprise at a TV display while a salesman runs a credit card machine over his hand. MELVIN (v.0.) Actin' all depraved and loose and wild.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: senator Charles Wingwood has stopped pouring himself a highball and stares wide-eyed at the broadcast on the TV in the backseat of his limousine. MELVIN (v.o.) Ninety miles from here. (speaking) Here they are, our own Melvin P. Thorpe Singers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men singers touch their fingertips to their hat brims the girl singers half curtsy and smile broad, vacant smil

dialogues.speaker: DOGETTES
dialogues.text: (singing) Texas has a whorehouse in it!  96 97 98 99

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Duicie Mae watching the show in her kitchen as she prepares dinner. Her twelve-year-old son, BILLY, is sitti at the table also watching. . MELVIN (v.o.) (singing) I'll not let this scandal fade!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edsel, the editor, is seated at his desk and can't believ what he's seeing. DOGETTES (v.o.) Texas has a whorehouse in it!

dialogues.speaker: EDSEL
dialogues.text: I'll be damned!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mayor watches from his living room chair. He chokes.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Doreen. Doreen! Run git my heart pills! Hurry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little guy, in his underwear, watches from a big chair. MELVIN (v.o.) I'll uproot and I'll crusade! I can smell corruption And I'll fight it to the top! Loveless copulation goin’ oooonnnnn. And it must stop! INT. CHICKEN RANCH PARLOR - NIGHT - Iv SET 100 The girls are watching it in the parlor. All are startled and happy to be on TV.

dialogues.speaker: GINGER
dialogues.text: Oh, my goodness. They're talking about us!  101 102 103 104

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. TV STATION STAGE — NIGHT 101

dialogues.speaker: DOGETTES
dialogues.text: Loveless copulation, stop that copulation! Loveless copulation, stop that copulation!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ex-boxer BARTENDER is staring with his few customers a the show on the small TV.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Loveless copulation? He picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 103 All over the state, people are grabbing for their phones. farmers, cowboys, oil riggers, maids, cooks, school teachers. Switchboards are a mass of activity as people in little vignettes sing to their neighbors. DOGETTES (v.o.) Texas has a whorehouse in it Lord have mercy on our souls Texas has a whorehouse in it Lord have mercy on our souls Watchdog smells corruption and He'll fight it to the top Loveless copulation goin’ on Goin' on, goin' on, goin' on.... We pull back from the litle vignettes to see them form a of Texas which dissolves into the smiling face of Melvin.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Don't touch that dial neighbors. I'll be back with new and revealing information on this and other cases. Watchdog never sleeps!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 104
dialogues.text: The Dogettes end the song while the audience joins in singing and swaying and the "applause" signs aré now flashing "Amen" and "Hallelujah."

dialogues.speaker: DOGETTES AND AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: (singing in counterpoint) And it must stop Watchdog's gonna get you He's gonna shine his light on you Watchdog's gonna get you Gonna shine his light on you. On the last beat, we pan over to the glass booth and push on Ed Eari's empty chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mona is pouring Ed Earl a cup of coffee as he tells her t problems caused by Melvin's TV show last night.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: That man is crazier than a peach orchard sow. Announcing it straight out, right there on tv!

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: So you've been saying.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: It's got everybody talking. Not because it's news to anyone over the age of three months, but because they are hearing it in their own damn living rooms. Sung...sung to music!

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Did he actually call my name?

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Not only that. The son-of-a-bitch called mine. Television! You know, we ain't caught a Peeping Tom in Lanville County in twenty-two years because all the Peeping Toms are home watching television!

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Well, Ed Earl, seems like ever since I can remember, folks have been ready to jump on me for one reason or another. (hugs him) we can beat it. we'll just sit tight 'til it all blows over. Besides I trust you. You're my protector.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: You know that man wears 4 sock in his underwear?

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: A sock?

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Yup. All rolled up like a Jimmy Dean sausage. Mona laughs. He stands

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: He's probably planning to run for office and is looking to get the Jesus bunch on his side. He's typical of all those crusading fanatics. They rise up talking hot and heavy, confusing crime with committing a sin, but they die down soon enough and everything goes back to normal.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: I suppose you're right.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Ain't I always? Now I suggest that tonight you and I hop over the county line, find a little beer hall and see if we can't forget all this fuss.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: That's the best idea I heard all day. up and is about to take her in his arms when we hear the sound of a honking horn outside. They stop.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: I wonder who that is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deputy Fred pulls up in his car, stops and comes running the steps. The girls on the swing begin to tease him. GINGER . Well, howdy Deputy Fred. How's your tallywhacker hanging?

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: Oh, quit embarrassing him. Anytime you want to lock me up honey, it's okay by me. Deputy Fred blushes and goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Earl comes out of the dining room and meets Deputy Fre the hall. He glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY FRED
dialogues.text: Howdy, Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: This better be important.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY FRED
dialogues.text: Well, I think it is. That Melvin - p. Thorpe is setting up his television show on the courthouse steps.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY FRED
dialogues.text: He's getting pictures for his report on the late news tonight. He's got a whole posse of TV cameramen and reporters. You better come look.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Well, I'll be a...Right in the middle of town!

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY FRED
dialogues.text: Un-huh. Right outside your office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ea Earl comes racing outside, followed by Deputy Fred. Mo follows them both.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: I can't believe that sucker.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY FRED
dialogues.text: You know, he's even prought his own singers. Ed Earl gets in his car. Mona rushes over to him.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Now, Ed Earl. Don't do anything you'll be sorry for. You watch that temper of yours.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: pon't worry about that, Mona. Just Jeave that little shithead to me. Ed Earl drives off. The girls on the porch cheer him on.

dialogues.speaker: TADDY JO
dialogues.text: Go get 'im, Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: Come on, Deputy Fred. Deputy Fred follows. The girls laugh, but Mona watches th with a worried look on her face. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melvin's Watchdog Chorus is singing a reprise of “Texas H A Whorehouse In It" in the courthouse gazebo. The crowd, including Dulcie Mae, looks on with amusement. The three old Nesters are playing dominoes. One looks up across the fountain.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST NESTER
dialogues.text: Look at that fella in them trick britches.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND NESTER
dialogues.text: It's too late in the year for the circus, ain't it?

dialogues.speaker: THIRD NESTER
dialogues.text: It's them TV folks, looks like to me. They grunt, go back to playing dominoes and never look up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melvin has a last minute touch-up on his makeup, slaps aw his assistant, signals to the cameraman and begins his report.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Howdy again, good neighbors! This is the ol' Watchdog, Melvin P. Thorpe, shining the spotlight on Gilbert -- the little town with the big shame. We're here at the Lanville County Courthouse to ask the local people how they feel about the infamous bordello running wide open in their American hometown. He walks up to the gazebo where the Dogettes are assemble and addresses the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Good people! Good people of Gilbert! May I have your attention! I would like to speak to you about a matter of great importance and concern.

dialogues.speaker: EDSEL
dialogues.text: Let's hear it, Melvin. Lay it on us.

dialogues.speaker: MANSEL
dialogues.text: Yeah, we can't hardly wait.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: I'm talking about nothing less than your community's moral health. I'm talking to you about official blindness, official corruption, official malfeasance.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE MAPLES
dialogues.text: What's that mean?

dialogues.speaker: MODENE ENNIS
dialogues.text: t don't know. I'm just waiting for Ed Earl to get here. He's gonna kick that boy's ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Earl is driving like a crazy man down the road, causin Deputy Fred behind him to be smothered in a cloud of dust  112

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dogettes are playing "Texas Has A Whorehouse In It” under Melvin's speech.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: It's no big secret! You know what's going on in this town. And what's going on is evil, immoral, brazen, and against the law. (singing) Oh...Texas Has A Whorehouse In It.

dialogues.speaker: DOGETTES
dialogues.text: Lord have mercy on our souls!

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Texas has a whorehouse in it!

dialogues.speaker: DOGETTES
dialogues.text: Lord have mercy on our souls!

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN DOGETTES
dialogues.text: Sin is runnin' rampant Ooooh, ooooh, Like before the fall Aaah, aaaaah. of Rome.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Someone is permittin' You know what. Eda Earl careens into the town square and screeches to a halt. He gets out. The Mayor, sensing danger, comes over to calm him.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Now, Sheriff, keep a grip on yourself. Don't start blowing your stack. :

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Quit whimpering, Rufus. He walks over to the gazebo. Melvin stops the singing.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: And here comes the man himself. Would you care to give me an interview now, Sheriff?

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: I'm giving you thirty seconds, you fancified fart, to get you and your singing chorus the hell out of town.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Now, wait a minute, Ed Earl.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Pack up them damn cameras and get this stuff off my street. You're blocking traffic. MELVIN ; The only traffic we're blocking 1s that headed out for the Chicken Ranch, right, Sheriff? A hushed crowd. Ed Earl cannot believe what he has heard. He pushes his hat brim up with a thumb and deliberately stalks up the steps. Standing six inches from Melvin, he looks him up and down, his gaze lingering on the outlandi three-color cowboy boots on Melvin's feet.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Little buddy, you got two tickets up to now. Parading without a license and insulting me. Now, you either get this halloween carnival out of here, or I'm gonna lock up your ass ‘til your baby's grown.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: we're perfectly within the law, Sheriff. As a newsman, I've got First Amendment protection. The public has a right to know what's going on out there, and what kind of payoff you're accepting to protect that notorious house of ill repute. There is a low moan from the crowd. ‘The locals know that the Sheriff has a low threshold for insults. Ed Earl begi slowly.

First thing. First thing is, you're standing in Lanville County. Which, by my figurin', is about a hundred miles west of that stinkhole you call Houston. So Tt can't see it's any of your business what goes on out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONTINUED - 2 il2 Melvin signals the cameraman to get a better angle on the Sheriff. The soundman follows with a directional mike, pointing it directly at Ed Earl.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Number two, number two is you ain't an officer of the law and I an. so don't go telling me what ny goddamn job is or, I'll whip your butt 'til it looks like stripes on a barber pole. The local people, according to their respective dispositi and allegiances, cheer or react in a shocked manner. Bill and his friends are delighted.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Git ‘im, Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: MODENE ENNIS
dialogues.text: (chortling) He may be mean, but he's ours!

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Three! No sawed-off little pecker is gunna accuse me of takin' a _ bribe and live to tell it, ‘cause I wear the badge in this goddamn county. So you listen good, you over-padded, televisin' turd, if I ever see you or any one of your other bastards in this town again, t'll knock you so flat you'll have to roll down your socks to shit.

dialogues.speaker: EDSEL
dialogues.text: That's tellin! him, Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: _ DULCIE MAE
dialogues.text: (laughing) Oh, my goodness! Ed Earl gets out his gun and points it at Melvin.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Now, get out of here, you goddamn wig-wearin' citified son-of-a-bitch! He fires his pistol into the air. Women scream, dogs bark and everyone starts to ecatter. The cameraman trips over camera and Melvin, in his hurry to flee, falls backward i

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: the fountain and almost loses his wig. Ed Earl keeps shoo The townspeople run for cover, put look on happily as Mel and the TV crew hop in their two trucks and drive away- E Earl puts his gun back in the holster and mutters proudly himself.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
