dialogues.text: So long, pardner. He looks around -- the crowd comes out from hiding and gi him a wild ovation. Billy is thrilled and points Ed Earl out to his friends. BILLY . He's my friend. He's coming over to my house to watch the Aggie game. Ed Earl is accepting the adulation of the crowd. He gets into his car. Dulcie Mae comes over. ’ DULCIE MAE You were wonderful, Ed Earl.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Thanks, Dulcie.

dialogues.speaker: DULCIE MAE
dialogues.text: We've finished serving lunch, but I did save you a piece of meatloaf. It's your favorite.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Well, no thank you. I have an official report to make about all this and I've got to go up to the Chicken Ranch and talk to Miss Mona.

dialogues.speaker: DULCIE MAE
dialogues.text: Oh, of course.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Catch you later. Ed Earl drives off to the cheers of the citizens. We push in on Dulcie Mae's face. She knows he's going out to celebrate with Mona and that he is in love with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fiddler is on the bandstand leading the band in a hoedo while the customers dance around the floor. Everyone is having a foot-stomping good time.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 113
dialogues.text: Mona and Ed Earl enter. She is ina simple dress and he is not in his uniform. They are in great high spirits and go over to the bar to order beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the beers on the table we see the time has passed. The band is taking a break and we seque into a record playing the jukebox. Mona, sitting at the table by herself, looks around as Ed Earl comes up to her.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Well, listen to that, it's my favorite Bob Wills song.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: I know. Why do you think I put it on? He offers her his hand. She smiles and takes it. They wal out to the dance floor and begin to dance as we hear Bob Wills sing "Faded Love." BOB WILLS (v.0.) (singing) As I look at the letters That you wrote to me It's you that I'm thinkin' of. As I read the lines That to me were so sweet I remember our faded love. Mona joins in singing with the record.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: I’11 miss you darling More and more every day As heaven would miss the stars above. with every heartbeat I will think of you i remember our faded love. As they dance around the floor we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ea Earl drives by in his truck with Mona snuggled up besi im.  116 117

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mona looks up at Ed Earl and smiles contentedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pull back from the campfire that Ed Earl has built by shore to reveal he and Mona lying up against a log and lo up at the heavens. They are quietly enjoying the peace of moment. Mona sighs.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Look at them stars. Ain't nothin‘ prettier than a Texas sky.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Ain't that the truth.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Hey! Did you see that shooting star?

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Mmmm .

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Do you think that might have been a spaceship? Do you believe in that sort of thing?

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Oh, sure. There's all kinds of strange things happening. I seen some pictures once of those little guys from outer space. They're about two feet high, have bald heads, tiny little legs and they got no peckers.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: well, then, I ain't interested and neither would any of my girls. You know, when I was little I used to dream about flying saucers coming down to get me and take me off to heaven. You know, like the angels. ‘And I looked and behold a whirlwind came out of the north...and out of the midst of the fire came the likeness of four living creatures.'

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: That's from Ezekiel. Haven't you ever heard of Ezekiel in the Bible?

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: gure, I've heard of the Bible. But the only Ezekiel I ever heard of is Ezekiel Peebles in the eighth grade. I busted his jaw once.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: That was very Christian of you, Ed Earl. :

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: well, we were all Baptists in my family.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: I never stayed with any one family long enough to become anything in particular. But I read the Bible and I do know about Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: I think Jesus was a nice person. Must have been a good speaker.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: You know, I knew a woman once who told me she had a vision of Jesus. He came right down and sat on the end of her bed one night. I believed her. I feel that could happen to me.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Well, if Jesus comes into your piace honey, all hell's gonna break oose.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: (laughing) I guess you got a point, Ed Earl. But you know, Jesus was very good to Mary Magdalene and she was a fallen woman. Isn't that amazing. She was perhaps his best friend. ED EARL . You mean Mary Magdalene was Jesus' girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Well, not the way you're thinking. But Jesus did like to have a good time. People seem to forget that. You know, he went to a wedding once

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MONA (Cont'd) and they ran out of wine. So you know what he did? He turned some water into wine. .

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Sounds like a man who knowed how to party.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Now, don't be sacrilegious, Ed Earl.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Oh, he knows I was kidding. He forgives me.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Yeah...I know he does. Ain't it funny. God can forgive you, but people can't. Why is that?

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Because most people ain't too God-like, honey.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: I know. I know. A pause as they look at the sky. Ed Earl begins to chuckl

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: That Melvin P. Thorpe is a sorry son-of-a-bitch.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: (laughing) Well, you sure sent him packing. I'm proud of you.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: You think he's really running for office?

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Well, I haven't told this to anyone yet, but I'm thinking of running for the legislature myself.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: You serious, Ed Earl?

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm serious. I've got my sights aimed higher than being a sheriff all my life. Besides, ! think I could do some good. A lot of people don't think an honest man can be elected, but I don't believe that. This is a great country and we've still got it in us.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Well, you've got my vote. I! might even go register.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: 1'd be a good politician, Mona. And you know why? Because I'd tell the truth. Nobody does that anymore and, by God, I'm going to give it a shot. .

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: I didn't know you had dreams that big, Ed Earl.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Well, it's one dream I believe I could pull off. People like me. It's natural to like me. You know, people like you, too. You'd be surprised if you took a poll around town.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: I hear it all the time. You're a well-liked lady.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Well, I always believed if you see somebody without a smile, give then yours.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: 1 like that. Do you think I could borrow that slogan when I run for the legislature...'I always believed if you see somebody without a smile, give them yours.' ...I could put that on my card.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: oh, Ed Earl. I guess I'm just not a person who believes in dreams. I believe in reality. Dreams have never gotten me anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: But how about when you were a kid. You must have wanted to be something.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Promise you won't laugh?

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: sure.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: I used to think I wanted to be a dancer. 1 wanted to be a ballerina. One of the first things I can remember was a little ballerina on top of a music box. I would just watch her for hours dancing round and round.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: well, I don't think it's too late for you to be a ballerina.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Oh, hell, Ed Earl. I'm so top-heavy, I have a hard enough time balancing these now without getting up on my toes.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Mona, you're wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Thank you...you know, I don't see anyone except you, Ed Earl. Not anymore. You can't say the same, can you. /

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: I don't go to bed with anyone elise.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: You don't?

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Not for three years now. You didn't know that, did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONTINUED - 5 ir

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: No, I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Well, I figure there's nothing better after you've had the best.

dialogues.speaker: MONA ,
dialogues.text: I like that. If I ever run for the legislature, I'm gonna put that on my card. They laugh. They kiss. They kiss again and fall into a passionate and loving embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mayor is watching television.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Next up, Melvin P. Thorpe continues his expose on the Chicken Ranch with a violent demonstration in the Gilbert town square. The Mayor reacts to seeing the announcement on television

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Great God from Goldsborough! Doreen. Doreen! Run git my heart pills!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the darkened room the phone is ringing. It rings three or four times. A hand comes out from under the blankets, turns on the overhead light and answers the phone. It is Earl. He sticks his head out from under the blankets.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mayor is on the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Ed Earl, you better turn on Channel 4. That Melvin P. Thorpe idiot has got you on TV again.  121

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Earl turns to Mona.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Honey, turn on the television. Channel 4. The Mayor says that Melvin P. Thorpe is spewing off at the mouth again. Mona reaches for the remote control for the TV on the nig table.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Calm down, Rufus, it can't be as bad as ali that. Mona turns on the television and we see Melvin seated at news desk giving his version of what happened in the Gilb town square.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: What happened to me, as an individual, is not important. But what Sheriff Dodd did to a constitutionally licensed newsman and a good tax-paying American citizen is important! It calls up old dark versions of Mussolini's Brown Shirts and the Nazi terrors. I think the film speaks for itself. On the television screen we see an edited version of Ed Earl's speech: a tle bleep No sawed-off little bleep is gunna accuse me of takin' a bribe and live to tell it... (fires gun) +..'cause I wear the badge in this bleep county. So you listen good, you bleep-bleep, bleep-bleep... ires gun, same shot) ..-if I ever see you or any one of you other bleep in this town again, I'il knock you so flat you'll have to bleep-bleep, bleep-bleep, eep! bleep- Dp (fires gun, same shot) Ed Earl and Mona watch in open-mouthed horror.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 12.
dialogues.text: MELVIN (v.o.) Is this the kind of man we want running our law enforcement? Is this the kind of foul-mouthed example we want to set for our children? Mona sadly shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Ed Earl, that man has made a fool of you. Ed Earl, in shock, absently hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mayor, Edsel and C.J. Vernon are pacing around Ed Ear outer office. The two phones are ringing and Rita has her hands full. Deputy Fred waits. The Mayor takes out his watch.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: I've had calls from four preachers, six deacons and the presidents of two garden clubs.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (hanging up) The phones have been ringing just like that all morning.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Don't know why I let people talk me into serving as the Mayor of this incorporated sand trap anyway. (looking at his watch) What the heck is keeping him?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: He'1li be along.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY FRED
dialogues.text: My wife couldn't believe what she saw last night. They bleeped him out, but she read his lips on every ‘hell', 'goddamn' and 'shit'.

dialogues.speaker: EDSEL
dialogues.text: Did you hear some folks are getting up a petition to close the Chicken Ranch?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 75 122 c.J. All we wanted to do was keep it iet. Now, thanks to Ed Earl, it's getting to be the hottest thing on the air since The Gong Show. Ed Earl enters and stops at Rita's desk for his messages.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Mornin', Sheriff. Here's your calls.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Mornin', Rita. Mornin’, fellers. I guess you're waiting to talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: We sure are. You don't know the trouble you've stirred up with this Chicken Ranch business. They follow Ed Earl into his office.

dialogues.speaker: C.J.
dialogues.text: Dammit, Ed Earl, if you aren't a pluperfect fool.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Maybe so. I've got calls here from a dozen shocked citizens telling me we've got a whorehouse operating in this county...for about a hundred and fifty years!

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Ed Earl, you can set up speed traps to catch the tourists, you can look the other way when the wrong kid swipes a car to go joyriding, hell, you can even allow Miss Mona to run her place out there. But the one thing you can't get away with is broadcastin' gutter talk on TV!

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: How was I supposed to know they were taking pictures?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 76 1 c.J. What did you figure the cameras were for?

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: You know, I'm getting just a little sick of all this bad mouthin'. Hell, the Chicken Ranch don't give me half as much trouble as those all night stag parties out at the Legionnaires Hall. c.g. (embarrassed) That ain't fair, ding it!

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: There's only one thing to do and that's close the place down before we all go to hell in a handbasket.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Close it down! Oh, you were all willing to go along with Miss Mona when things were running good because she brought business to the town and made civic contributions. But now that she's in trouble, you're all about to turn tail and run like rats from a burning barn.

dialogues.speaker: EDSEL
dialogues.text: That's just it, Ed Earl. But who's going to put out the fire?

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Look, if you won't close her down, at least tell her to lay low for a couple of months. C.J. Just until the heat wears off.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Give it two months. What's two months? :

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Dammit, Rufus. I don't want anybody telling me how to do my job. I'm still the law here and I'll make up my own mind about what's gotta be done!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Earl is talking to Mona.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Two months. What's two months?

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Shut down for two months! That's a hell of a lot of overhead to pay out when a company's cash is not coming in. What am I supposed to tell my girls?

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Maybe it won't be two months. The holidays are coming up. Maybe in a couple of weeks it will have all blown over and you can start letting your regular customers in the back door.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: You know, I warned you before you left yesterday about losing your temper...shouting and carrying on.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Last night you said you were proud of me.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Last night I wasn't on the eleven o'clock news!

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: I didn't know they were going to make me out to look like an idiot. I don't understand this electronic bullshit. How was I supposed to handle it?

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: That's your job. That's what you're paid for.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: I know what my job is. I know I can have this whole place shut down in a New York minute. But all I'm asking for is a little cooperation from you so we can get through this difficult situation with as little trouble as possible.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Okay. Okay. I'11 shut down.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: You promise?

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: What do you want, a written contract? I give you my word.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: I'm really sorry this had to happen.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Don't feel sorry for me. I started out poor and worked my way up to outcast.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Mona, I hate this, dammit, I really do. I don't want this to hurt our relationship, but I. really believe this is the best answer. If you'll just trust me. Mona is quite moved with his honest expression of emotion She turns, smiles, and gives him a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Oh, you big cowboy, I do trust you. Ain't I always? She gives him a hug. He kisses her lightly on the cheek and, with a flourish, puts on his hat. He turns and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Earl is coming down the stairs just as Jewel, carrying pile of sheets, is coming up.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Well, if it ain't the celebrated cussing Sheriff of Lanville County. How are you Sheriff?

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Fine. How are you, Porky?

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: (laughing) Now, Sheriff, I been real good all week. I dropped six pounds.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: What did you do, lose a finger? Ed Earl] continues down the stairs and out the door. Jewe laughing, walks up to Mona.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: I've just promised the Sheriff to shut the place down for two months.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: What? How can you promise that? What about the football game celebration tomorrow night?

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Oh, I forgot.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: It's the Thanksgiving game, Miss Mona. That's real special.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Yes, I know. Well, okay. But we'll be closed for all regulars. Do you think that'll be all right? JEWEL © I'm sure it will, honey. That party's a tradition.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, FOOTBALL STADIUM
dialogues.text: The traditional Thanksgiving Day rivalry between the Texa Aggies and the Texas Longhorns 18 in full swing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ANNOUNCER, looking down over the field, is talking in the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Well folks, this game has turned into a real stem-winder, The Texas Aggies, favored to lock up the Southwest Conference and waltz into the Cotton Bowl in Dallas for a happy New Year, are fighting for their football lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on the field, we see regular football action as the Announcer's voice continues. ANNOUNCER (v.0.) The Longhorns are playing tough defensive ‘ball, making this traditional Thanksgiving Day classic one for the record s books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Earl and Billy are watching the game on the television the living room. Thanksgiving decorations are on the mant In the kitchen, Dulcie Mae takes the turkey out of the ov she Looks over at her son sitting happily with Ed Earl on couch.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Come on, Aggies, plow those Longhorns! ‘ga Earl laughs and pops a beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘Some of the girls are putting up the decorations while the TV with the football game plays in the parlor. Out in the hall, Angel is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Well, I sure do hope Mummy will be home for Christmas, punkin'. Now you have a good Thanksgiving and put Grandma back on...Mummy loves you, baby.... Jewel walks by with double sets of colored crepe paper ribbons and holds them up for the girls in the main room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll string up the white first and then see who wins before we add the orange or maroon.

dialogues.speaker: GINGER
dialogues.text: I cain't stand it if them Aggies win.

dialogues.speaker: DAWN
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: GINGER
dialogues.text: They're such animals. Always yelling and jumping about and saying 'Yeee-haaw!'

dialogues.speaker: ELOISE
dialogues.text: I like that.

dialogues.speaker: RUBY RAE
dialogues.text: We had two Aggies here last year. They went upstairs to shoot craps -- and blew a hole in the toilet. The girls all laugh, but Shy is a little backward.

dialogues.speaker: SHY
dialogues.text: Really? What did Miss Mona say?

dialogues.speaker: . JEWEL
dialogues.text: She's putting you on, darlin’.

dialogues.speaker: RUBY RAE
dialogues.text: The hell I am. Those boys are dumb.

dialogues.speaker: GINGER
dialogues.text: Dumb ain't the word. You hear about the time the Aggie coach went up to the quarterback and asked him, ‘Do you think you can pass this ball?' ‘Hell, yes,' said the Aggie quarterback.

dialogues.speaker: GINGER AND RUBY RAE
dialogues.text: (laughing together ) If I can swallow it. The girls all join in laughing and now Shy sees that they are making Aggie jokes. She smiles. Ginger looks over at the television set.

dialogues.speaker: GINGER
dialogues.text: Come on, Longhorns! Hold that line!  131 132 133 134

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: What a finish we've got here, folks. The Aggies are out of the huddle, twenty short ticks of the clock from oblivion. The underdog Longhorns lead twelve to seven, with the Aggies in business on the thirty-five yard line.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, FOOTBALL FIELD
dialogues.text: We see the play as it is described. ANNOUNCER (v.o.) Bubba Shrake takes the snap and drops back to pass. He's got good protection...he's looking deep. Shrake throws over the middie. (shouts) Sliney's got it at the five! He's hit and he's short of the goalline. He's stopped short! And he calls time! Time out on the field with three seconds left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two ENGINEERS are watching the game on monitors.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST ENGINEER
dialogues.text: I'll bet those boys are creaming in their pants. You know that whichever team wins gets a celebration dinner tonight at the Chicken Ranch.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND ENGINEER
dialogues.text: Yeah. Course, it don't matter what the scoreboard says, the real winner of today's game is gonna be Miss Mona. They laugh. We pan off the Enginerrs and see that Melvin has overheard their conversation. He looks up at the monitor and smiles with gleeful expectation.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Just three seconds left on the scoreboard clock. The Aggies trailing twelve to seven on the five-yard line, needing a touchdown to win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: atin {QOTRALL FIELD - DAY 138 Me see the action described by the Announcer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The (be es ¢ & Geule ee put ySde: ee Ene growing shake 2B — serriane, MB poe sae ig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or dines: He? 3" er apa ee ‘pf ae" ange ei The eran pgue ng onte the field. ee ea PLE a ah a A ee estefan vere EGn* <

dialogues.speaker: TRE
dialogues.text: Baek duane saercts an op ups sofa with Geliaht, while TNT. TEE CHICRER RANCH = AIK Re = BAY 337 pais nig one He Bh aytbien® the giths. The celebration is wpe won CERCER ay vey UNAS me ‘sey te Ths, Sashes, “ oy ane, pe meee tae over at Ginger andy, a8 if Gh Gite, the othe

dialogues.speaker: GIRLS,
dialogues.text: Xesehaau},  ~~ «138

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Aggies come down into the locker room, all breathless and excited.

dialogues.speaker: AGGIES
dialogues.text: Yeeeehaaaw! Senator Wingwood and the alumni welcome them.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR
dialogues.text: Boys! Boys! That was the greatest victory since General Eisenhower . won! You make me glad to be an Aggie. I swear, I could break down and cry like a baby, I'm so flushed with pride.... one of the Aggies is tossing bottles of Lone Star Beer to his teammates as they enter. He tosses one to the Senator

dialogues.speaker: AGGIE
dialogues.text: Have a Lone Star on us, Senator.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR
dialogues.text: Now, you boys know senators don't drink! It ain't good for the Baptist vote. He pops it open and it sprays across the room. One of the Aggies does a few bars of a foot-stompin' cleat dance. Th others cheer for him. A lot of “yee-haw's."

dialogues.speaker: AGGIE
dialogues.text: Hey, Senator, you ain't forgot you was gonna take us to the Chicken Ranch, have you?

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR
dialogues.text: (leering) I always keep my campaign promises! Cheers from the team.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR
dialogues.text: yes sir, the Chicken Ranch is a fine institution and I'm proud to have it in my district. And to hell with what Melvin P. Thorpe says. So let's get a move on and we'll see you boys at Miss Mona's. He and his party exit.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 138
dialogues.text: The Aggies all cheer and the true celebration starts. The are pulling off their pads and uniforms. Various angles o the different players like LEROY SLINEY, the young wide receiver, and BARNEY SCRUGGS, the ox-like defensive lineman. They begin to sing.

dialogues.speaker: AGGIES
dialogues.text: (singing) We're gonna whomp And stomp And whoop it up tonight Those little gals won't never ever Be the same. They're gonna love it when we whomp And stomp And whoop it up all right It's even better than an Aggie Football game.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (dumbly) Better than a football game?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Various angles of the Aggies showering.

dialogues.speaker: AGGIES
dialogues.text: And then we're gonna show them all A thing or two We're gonna demonstrate Just what A champion can do Yee-Haw! We're gonna play 'em out and Lay ‘em out tonight They won't have never seen nobody Quite like me -- huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Aggies come out of the showers and, snapping their towels and horsing around, go to their lockers to begin getting dressed.

dialogues.speaker: AGGIES
dialogues.text: We're gonna wham and bam and Thank you ma'am tonight I swear I don't know how they'll Stand such ecstasy -- huh Right between the goalpost.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 140
dialogues.text: They put on their blue jeans and cowboy boots and sing.

dialogues.speaker: AGGIES
dialogues.text: We been deprived so long But now we're gettin’ some I bet the girls are countin' up The minutes 'til we come. An Aggie pops up from behind a locker.

dialogues.speaker: AGGIE
dialogues.text: They ain't the only ones. Peach-fuzzed, clear-voiced Leroy Sliney pushes a laundry cart down the middle of the locker room.

dialogues.speaker: LEROY
dialogues.text: Seventy-five miles until we get to heaven.

dialogues.speaker: AGGIES
dialogues.text: Seventy-five miles until our Plans are laid Seventy-five miles until we get to The Chicken Ranch Where history _And Aggie boys Get made. The boys spin the cart around and begin the big dance num After a spectacular series of acrobatics and clogging, th Aggies, now fully dressed with shirts and hats, charge ou of the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a helicopter we see the Aggie bus driving down a country road. We push in just as Leroy sticks his head ou a window.

dialogues.speaker: LEROY
dialogues.text: Twenty-two miles until we get To heaven. Other Aggies stick their heads out.

dialogues.speaker: AGGIES
dialogues.text: Twenty-two miles until our Plans are laid Twenty-two miles until we get To the Chicken Ranch.  142 143 144 145

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole team, with their hats in their hands, joyfully sticks their heads out the windows.

dialogues.speaker: AGGIES
dialogues.text: Where history And Aggie boys Get made. The rear tire blows out and the truck careens to a halt b the side of the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jewel is distributing some of the ball gowns to the girls Shy picks one up and is admiring it, but Ginger is very bored with the idea.

dialogues.speaker: GINGER
dialogues.text: Do we have to wear these ball gowns again?

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Yes, you do, and I don't want to hear any bitchin' about it. Miss Mona tries to create something special for these boys -- it's like a graduation dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silhouetted against the setting sun, the Aggies are packe stacked and hanging all over a small pickup truck driven a somewhat confused old farmer. Leroy is holding onto the roof with one hand and sings excitedly.

dialogues.speaker: LEROY
dialogues.text: One more mile until we get To heaven.

dialogues.speaker: AGGIES
dialogues.text: One more mile until our Plans are laid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pickup truck drives up the hill to the front gate.

dialogues.speaker: AGGIES
dialogues.text: One more mile until we get To the Chicken Ranch Where history And Aggie boys Get made. Leaping and jumping off the pickup truck, the Aggies danc up to the front porch and knock on the Chicken Ranch door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jewel opens the door and welcomes them. They enter polite hats in hand. Senator Wingwood has already arrived and he greets them when suddenly all heads turn to Miss Mona as makes one of her grand entrances down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR
dialogues.text: (to Mona) Howdy, ma'am. I'm Senator Wingwood of the 19th District and Aggie Class of '49. Mighty proud to meetcha.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Meet me? Come on, Charlie. How's Mary Margaret and the kids? The Aggies all laugh and the Senator is momentarily embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: . SENATOR
dialogues.text: Hell, Miss Mona. I didn't think you'd remember.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: You remember to bring the check?

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR
dialogues.text: 1 got it right here. He produces it from his coat pocket and hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: It's a business doing pleasure with you, Senator. She rings the bell.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Come on, boys. We've got a surprise for you. She leads everyone out to the back.  147 148

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Mona enters with the Aggies as the girls are coming down the backstairs or waiting beneath the colored lanter strung out over the punch bowl. They are all wearing thei ball gowns and look slightly reminiscent of a high school prom. The Aggies break into whistles and catcalls and beg pairing off for an encore of the Aggie dance. Leroy spots Shy and he pairs up with her. Mona signals Ginger to take the Senator off her hands. The high point of the number comes when the girls snap of their bali gowns (held in place by Velcro) and appear in their latest Frederick's of Hollywood underwear.

dialogues.speaker: AGGIES
dialogues.text: Yeeeehaaaaw! The stomping becomes frenetic and the dance ends with the couples facing off inside or upstairs looking for a bedro The Senator goes with Ginger. Leroy goes off with Shy. Mona looks over at Jewel, gives her a look that says "Wel that's that," and turns off the party lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Earl is leaving after having Thanksgiving dinner with Dulcie Mae.

dialogues.speaker: DULCIE MAE
dialogues.text: Thank you for spending time with Billy. He really idolizes you.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. He's a great kid. And you're a great cook.

dialogues.speaker: DULCIE MAE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: DULCIE MAE
dialogues.text: I hope everything works out with this Melvin P. Thorpe business. I know it's been worrying you.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: It'll all blow over soon.

dialogues.speaker: DULCIE MAE
dialogues.text: Of course it will. After all, the Chicken Ranch has been there for years. And Miss Mona...well, she does a lot of good in town.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Yes. She does. (pause) Well, it's late. (kisses her on the cheek) Thank you, Dulcie. You're real sweet and you're real special to me.

dialogues.speaker: DULCIE MAE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Ed Earl.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Good night, honey. He hops in his car and drives home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deputy Fred is making his rounds, walking across the deserted town square. A TV van goes by. He stops and looks. A car follows. He looks again. Melvin P. Thorpe in the Watchdog van drives by. The Deputy scratches his head and thinks about that for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mona is in her bedroom going over her accounts. She opens her ledgers and sits at her desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leroy is contentedly smoking a cigarette. We pan over at Shy looking at him demurely from the pillow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jewel has her feet up watching an old movie on television The house is very quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Earl, in his boxer shorts, is brushing his teeth getti ready for bed. There is a knock at the front door. He goe to answer it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Earl crosses the living room, turning on the lights as goes. He opens the door. It's Deputy Fred.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY FRED
dialogues.text: Good evening, Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: This better be important.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY FRED
dialogues.text: Well, I think it is. I was making my rounds in town when I just saw that Melvin P. Thorpe drive through with some other fellers on their way to the Chicken Ranch.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Well, he's going to be real disappointed. There's nothing going on up there. Miss Mona's shut down for two months on my orders.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY FRED
dialogues.text: No, she ain't, Sheriff. Hell... (laughs) I saw those Aggie boys up there tonight celebrating to beat the band.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Huh? Huh...Holy shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone has gone to bed. The lights are low. We pan down from Mona at her desk in her bedroom to shadows creeping along the Chicken Ranch wall. It is Melvin and his crew o cameramen and reporters (eight in all). They reach the lattice door to the backyard and, with a pair of chain eutters, cut the lock. Melvin turns to the camera, signal to switch it on and addresses his audience. MELVIN . Now we're going to take you into the whorehouse itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melvin and his crew creep along the back porch and sneak inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pass the parlor where Jewel has fallen asleep in fro of a television station that has gone off the air. Melvin

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 157
dialogues.text: positions his men near the light switches, then stands by the bell and gives the signal.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Okay, everybody up! The bel] clangs, all the lights in the house turn on and with a charging yell, Melvin and his crew go running up t stairs and through the whorehouse. Jewel wakes up and fal off her chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mona looks up and reacts to the noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The still photographers throw open the doors and burst in snapping pictures with flash cameras of couples in bed. Girls scream, boys jump out of bed and start putting on their clothes, knocking over tables and water bowls as th do so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melvin bursts into a room, followed by his cameraman. He turns to address his television audience while the startl customer in bed looks around.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Now we're going to talk to some of the girls and their customers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is in pandemonium. Boys and girls are running everywhere, screaming and shouting "raid." Mona comes out of her room and sees Jewel coming up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: It's that Melvin P. Thorpe sucker and his TV reporters. Mona runs back into her room while Jewel grabs a still ph rapher who is running by her and starts belting him in th mouth. One of his friends comes to his assistance and Jew karate chops him over the bannister.  wm 162 163 164 165 oo 166 167 o~

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mona dials the Sheriff's office to bring assistance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A montage of shots. An Aggie gets out from under a bed asking, "What's up?" Another Aggie leaves his girl, sayin “wait until next year" and rushes off. We see a foursome bed surprised by a photographer, while in another room a and girl are so stoned out on a joint that they look arou and mutter "Far out!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mona is getting no response from her phone call. She hang up in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melvin bursts in on the Senator, who, with a highball in hand, is being doused in baby powder by a blonde. Melvin sticks a microphone in front of the startled Senator's fa

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Senator, the eyes of Texas are upon you. The Senator looks stupidly about in the haloed light of t powder-filled air. He sees the television camera and jump out of bed and runs into a closet, slamming the door behi him. Melvin laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: I think we've got enough. Let's get out of here. He and his crew run off down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mona takes down a rifle from her wall and goes out to the landing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Football players are running out of the house and jumping inte the Aggie bus. With his siren wailing, Ed Earl and Deputy Fred are driving up to the Chicken Ranch. Melvin a

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: gp 167 168 oo oo

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 167
dialogues.text: his crew are hopping into their vans and the car. Ed Earl drives up in a cloud of dust and parks. He gets out and looks at the scrambling Aggies. Mona appears at the front door with her rifle. Just then, Melvin drives from behind the bus and speeds off towards the front gate. He passes Ed Earl and laughs as he snaps a picture. We push in on E Earl. He shakes his head with anger.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Holy, shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Earl and Mona are in the midst of a furious argument.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: You promised me, dammit! You gave me your word and I took it. I'm the law. I could have....

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: The law! A gang of crazies break into my house, invading my privacy, taking pictures. Just tell me what the law is going to do about that! I'll tell you. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: They wouldn't have any reason to be here if you'd done what you said you'd do. I trusted you. That's what hurts. I trusted you!

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Don't talk to me about trust. I trusted you to protect me. So I made a mistake tonight, okay!

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: If that's your idea of apologizing....

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: I ain't apologizing. I'ma businesswoman paying out double taxes and I expect a little security for my money. Where were you? Where were your deputies?

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: I was at home because I thought....

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: When Sheriff Jack Roy Wallace was running things, this could never have happened. But you, you just can't handle the job! ED . Goddamit, Mona, you're getting me mad!

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: That's right, cuss and shout just like on TV. You're still a kid playing at being a cowboy. You're never going to grow up. You use me as your mistress, you use that damn Dulcie Mae in town as your on-call wife, you even use her son so you can play weekend daddy. But that's all it is, Ed Earl, playing. And that's all you are, a kid playing at being a man. Ed Earl grabs his hat and turns in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: I don't have to listen to this crap. Just remember, I'm wearing the badge and the only reason your doors stay open is because of me.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Don't threaten me. I'm telling the truth and you know it. Your big dreams of going to the legislature, that's all they are...dreams. ‘Cause you'll always be what you are right now -- a chicken-shit sheriff in a chicken-shit town.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Maybe so, but that's a damn sight better than being a whore! As soon as he said it, Ed Earl wishes he hadn't. Mona turns to him. Tears are welling up in her eyes. Ed Earl slams his fist against the dressing table and bre the glass. He turns around and storms out. Mona watches and listens as he goes down the stairs and out the front door. She falls down on the bed and sobs uncontrollably.  169

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the early morning light we discover Ed Earl, unshaven remorseful, having stayed up all night strolling by the riverbank, alone with his thoughts. After a series of shots, he begins to sing.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Sometimes I get crazy As fools are known to do Lose my head in spite of Everything I stand to lose What is it in a man That makes him act like Such a fool I swear I never knew But always needed to. Stubborn pride is just the way of stallions I suppose Even love can't change The things I want to change the most And it's pride that's got me standin' When I should be on my knees Making apologies But it's so damn hard for me. Oh, but now and again I wish I'd a been a poet So I could know the perfect lines To say Have some great romantic way To show it Be the hero ridin' up To save the day. And I'd go ridin' high Like a knight in shining armor Just sweep her up and race into the sun But I don't have no magic ways To charm her No, it's lonely in the fields Where stallions run. And I'd like to say I love you But those words just don't come Words like that are no match For the kind that rule my tongue But I can only hope she knows I love her anyway No matter what I say Oh, but I never say.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ED EARL (Cont'd) Oh, now and again I wish I'd a been a poet So I could know the perfect lines To say And have some great romantic way To show it Be the hero that rides up To save the day. But I'd never be a knight In shining armor And as for poets I was never one I'm just a fool that must Restore his honor Oh, the winds are cold That blow where stallions run. I'm just a fool that must Restore his honor Or only walk in fields Where stallions run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER CRONKITE, at the anchor desk, is reporting the Chicken Ranch story to all America.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Legalized prostitution -- pro or con -~ is in the news again today. We now take you to Jeff Gerald in Gilbert, Texas. We pan off the "No Entry" sign across the front road lead to the Chicken Ranch up to JEFF GERALD with a microphone, talking into the camera. Some deputies and a few sightsee are parked in the background.

dialogues.speaker: GERALD
dialogues.text: The Chicken Ranch, the legendary long-running bawdy house is showing little activity after the disclosure yesterday of the Thanksgiving night raid. A deputy at the front gate keeps away onlookers and potential customers,

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 170
dialogues.text: GERALD (Cont'd) while up at the house, the shutters are closed and the principals not talking. We cut to newsreel film shot earlier where we catch a glimpse of Mona behind the window curtains and Jewel shoo off reporters from the front porch. We also see a cut of Earl walking from his car to his office, refusing to talk the press. GERALD (v.o.) The Sheriff of Gilbert, Ed Earl Dodd, refused interviews; while in Houston the man who launched the - campaign, consumer advocate Melvin P. Thorpe, held a press conference this afternoon. We cut to filmed footage shot in Melvins's studio.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: I have a report here that says the Chicken Ranch is involved with and under the influence of organized crime and I will be taking this report to Austin in the hope that the Governor will come out of his long silence on this issue. and uphold the law. After an establishing shot of the Austin Capitol, we cut a press conference in Senator Wingwood's office. GERALD (v.o.) At the Capitol today, the Governor made no statement, but Senator Charles Wingwood, who was a principal figure in the Watchdog News raid, also held a press conference explaining his involvement. The Senator nervously reads his prepared statement.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR
dialogues.text: I have no independent recollection of going to the Chicken Ranch and I can only say as the most dedicated anti-communist in the state

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: SENATOR (Cont'd) legislature that I must have been drugged by communists or communist sympathizers and placed there to harm my reputation and good name... So I am now calling on every freedom-loving American to call the Governor and have this shameful place shut down. In the town square of Gilbert, Gerald has set up his came and is about to interview some local citizens.

dialogues.speaker: GERALD
dialogues.text: Reaction across the state is split fifty/fifty, but in the town of Gilbert itself, the Chicken Ranch has many. supporters. We cut to Edsel, the newspaper editor.

dialogues.speaker: EDSEL
dialogues.text: I've never seen anything bad come from it and I've lived here all my life. It brings in business for the community and they pay taxes, same as anyone else. Besides, no one ever was forced to go up there. We cut to HENRY, a tough, redneck farmer.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: The Chicken Ranch? I think it's a good idea. You take a lot of young boys, they're going to be looking for women. If they can't find 'em, they'll rape ‘em, and if they don't do that, they'll run to other women and get diseases. Those girls went to doctors. We cut to DORA, a sweet and proper old lady in town.

dialogues.speaker: DORA
dialogues.text: My Frank, when he was alive, used to go up there every Saturday. I took it as a blessing. Course it was different then. Nowadays women enjoy doing that sort of thing themselves -- least that's what I've been told.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: We cut to Gerald for the wrap-up. He is standing in front of the Gilbert courthouse.

dialogues.speaker: GERALD
dialogues.text: Although petitions are being circulated to 'Save the Chicken Ranch' this bumper sticker is already beginning to appear around the state: He holds up a sticker saying "Pluck the Chicken Ranch."

dialogues.speaker: GERALD
dialogues.text: And so, as feminists line up behind the bill for the decriminalization of prostitution already in the legislature and as traditionalists and fundamentalists lobby for its defeat, the fate of the Chicken Ranch rests with the Governor, who today was again unavailable for comment. Jeff Gerald, CBS News in Gilbert, Texas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little man in the big chair watches the close of the report. He picks up a glass of water and drops in an Alka Seltzer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mona has been watching the Cronkite report with Jewel. Sh turns it off. They both know the serious trouble they're in.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: I hate admittin' I was wrong, Miss Mona, but with television broadcasting this from hell to breakfast, we should have done what the Sheriff said and kept this place closed.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: It was my decision, Jewel. It was my fault.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: om 172

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: He ain't gonna be able to stop it, this time, is he?

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: I think he'd probably like to, but he's out of his league. He doesn't know how to fight them. He's just a good old boy that will never grow up.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Honey, you see everything in this profession, but one thing I ain't even seen, man or woman, is a grownup. Don't be too hard on him. He loves you.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: He's never said it.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Some men can't say the words, honey, but that don't mean they don't feel it in their heart.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Maybe it's just as well. I set my course a long time ago and I can't be changing now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mayor, Edsel, C.J. and Mansel are talking over the problems of the week. Ed Earl is seated at the counter drinking a beer with his back towards the others. Dulcie Mae is listening and watching Ed Earl as the others discu the situation.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know what to do anymore. It seems folks got nothing to talk about but this Chicken Ranch mess. It's like a broken record: Chicken Ranch -- Chicken Ranch -- Chicken Ranch -- Chicken Ranch! c.J. This bad publicity's flat ruining business.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: I haven't sold a car all week.

dialogues.speaker: MANSEL
dialogues.text: It’s ruining the town. No one's blaming you, Ed Earl. It ain't your fault. But we can't just sit around waiting to grow tits.

dialogues.speaker: EDSEL
dialogues.text: The way I see it, the Chicken Ranch served a purpose once, but everything's opened up today. Why, we've undergone a worldwide sexual revolution. Miss Mona's place is not obscene. It's just obsolete. C.J. She ain't got a handful of supporters left, Ed Earl. Ali this publicity is making folks think twice about signing that petition to keep her open.

dialogues.speaker: MANSEL
dialogues.text: Why the hell don't that station in Houston turn their cameras to the cesspool in their own backyard.

dialogues.speaker: EDSEL
dialogues.text: Or Austin. Within two blocks of the Capitol building you can get anything done to you for money that you can get in Tangiers! Tongue baths, naked massages, somebody ticklin’ your ass with a feather. C.J. If you know that for a fact, Mr. Newspaper Editor, it's your duty to expose it.

dialogues.speaker: EDSEL
dialogues.text: C.J., I don't give a damn if folks occasionally want their asses tickled with feathers. I'd kinda like to think that's what heaven's all about. Ed Earl finishes his beer and slams it down. He turns around and faces them.

dialogues.text: Boys! I got myself a pretty good bulishit detector. And after

dialogues.text: ED EARL (Cont'd) listening to you I can damn sure tell when somebody's peeing on my boots and telling me it's a rainstorm. He gets up and puts on his hat.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: This thing has gotten way out of hand. I don't know how. It just sort of ate me up before I knew it was hungry. But I do know there is one thing I can still do.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL

dialogues.text: He'll see me. He opens the door and steps outside. Dulcie Mae follows.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: I feel like a country dog in the city. If I stand still, they screw me. If I run, they bite me in the ass. She smiles in spite of herself.

dialogues.speaker: DULCIE MAE

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Thanks...They all want me to close her down. Have her leave town. But how can I tell her to leave when all I want her to do is stay. He smiles at her sadly and walks across the street to his car. She knows that's the first protestation of love he's ever made. She has tears in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are still discussing Ed Earl's plan.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Ed Earl's a damn fool. Driving up to Austin to see the Governor. Don't he know that's hopeless.

dialogues.speaker: EDSEL
dialogues.text: Oh, he knows it's hopeless. c.J. Then why is he going?

dialogues.speaker: EDSEL
dialogues.text: Because that's what being a Texan is all about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of reporters is standing outside the Governor's house waiting for him to appear. An AIDE comes out and addresses them like a herald.

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen. His Excellency, the Governor of Texaaassss! The Aide and entourage clap wildly as the Governor steps the front door to accept the reception. It is the little man that we have seen earlier. The Governor beams, waves his cowboy hat and quiets the fanfare as if he were facin twelve thousand instead of a dozen.

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: Mah frens, I want to thank you for that sincere and heartwarming ovation.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 176
dialogues.text: He walks with his phalanx of aides past the reporters who clamor and call for his attention.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE REPORTER
dialogues.text: Governor, what do you think of the explosive situation in the Middle East?

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: I was saying just this morning, at the weekly prayer breakfaet in this historic Capitol, that it behooves both the Jews and the A-rabs to settle their differences in a Christian manner. The Governor's Aide and other flaks applaud as the Govern moves towards his limousine waiting at the bottom of the steps.

dialogues.speaker: MALE REPORTER
dialogues.text: Governor, Governor, sir. Have you seen the evidence of the disgraceful situation at the Chicken Ranch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Governor stops at the bottom of the steps. He turns t face the reporters and clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: R
dialogues.text: (singing) Fellow Texans I am proudly Standing here to humbly say I assure you And I mean it Now who says I don't speak Out as plain as day? And fellow Texans I'm for progress And the flag, long may it fly. I'm a poor boy Come to greatness So it follows that I cannot tell A liet He hops into his car and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE REPORTER
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: MALE REPORTER
dialogues.text: Same as usual...all hat and no cattle. \ We pan with the Governor's limo as it takes the short rid across the park to the Capitol. INT. LIMOUSINE - DAY 17€ The Governor is very pleased with himself. He sits in the backseat and his feet tap out a rhythm on the car floor.

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: (singing) Oooo! I love to Dance the little Sidestep Now they see me, Now they don't I've come and gone... And oo900ce! I love to sweep around A widestep Cut a littie Swath and lead The people on.

dialogues.text: As the limousine drives up and the Governor steps out, another group of reporters is waiting for him. He gets ou of the limousine and walks up the stepe.

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: (singing) Now my good friends It behooves me To be solemn and declare I'm for goodness And for profit And for living clean And saying daily prayer. And now my good friends You can sleep nights I'll continue to stand tall You can trust me For I promise I shall keep a watchful Eye upon you all. The reporters look bewildered as the Governor disappears into the Capitol.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE REPORTER
dialogues.text: Did you get any of that?

dialogues.speaker: MALE REPORTER
dialogues.text: I hear him talkin', but he don't come in.

dialogues.text: The Governor looks out through the glass doors at the confused reporters and chuckles to himself.

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: (singing) Oooo! I love to Dance the little Sidestep Now they see me, Now they don't I've come and gone... And ocoocooo! I love to sweep around A widestep Cut a little Swath and lead The people on. Tripping the light fantastic, the Governor shuffles insid  181 182

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR

I love to sweep around A widestep cut a little Swath and lead The people on. The Governor dances his final chorus, ending with a big finish that ushers him into his office as the music ends.

dialogues.text: The Governor leans against the door and with a sigh of satisfaction wipes the sweat from his brow. He goes to hi desk as MABEL, a plump and proper lady, bursts in from hi outer office. .

dialogues.text: Swearing Sheriff Dodd?..The one on television? I can't.... Eda Earl enters and interrupts.

dialogues.text: Governor, you've just got to listen to me...i know my coming here is way out of line but before you go closing the Chicken Ranch I want you to know the facts.

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR,
dialogues.text: Well, I haven't made that decision yet. My aides are working....

dialogues.text: The Chicken Ranch, Governor, has been in my county since before I was born. Its doors have been open “to soldiers and presidents and farmers and even governors who can remenb ex what a great institution t is.

dialogues.text: No need to bring that up, Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: -ED EARL
dialogues.text: I'm not threatening you, Governor. You hold the whiphand. Whatever you say I'm going to do, but think of the people out there. I've known Miss Mona for twelve years and there's no finer woman that you'll ever meet. The town likes her. She never refuses a charity -- the hospital fund, a new swimming pool. Hell, she even bought uniforms for the Little League so they wouldn't have to play in their blue jeans.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: oo 185

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: well, I wasn't aware of her civic generosity, but the law is the law.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: And sometimes it's got to be changed. Look, I've been fighting crime all my life, but let's not confuse crime with committing a gin. You can't legislate morality. Those girls out there have never caused any trouble. No fights. No dope. No nothing. They're healthy, tax-paying, law-abiding citizens who supply a demand and provide an economic asset to the community.

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: Ed Earl, you ever thought of running for office? You make that whorehouse sound like a damn non-profit recreational facility.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Governor, if the citizens who ‘elected me had found it necessary to close it for any reason, I would do it. I£ Miss Mona and her girls were jeopardizing the health, wealth or moral scruples of the community, I would do it. If the place had even been just a piddlin' nuisance, an eyesore, or even a fire hazard, I would close it down. But there's nothing! No reason, except the cries of this muckraking sensationalist on television. Half a dozen aides rush in.

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: Here they are, Governor. What you've been waiting for. The Governor takes the sheets of paper and scans them. He sighs and looks over to Ed Earl.

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Ed Earl. The Chicken Ranch loses, forty-two to thirty-seven, with twenty-one per cent undecided.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: (confused) What is that?

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: The polls! You can't ask me to go against the polls! This is what the people want. {to his aides) Is Melvin still outside? Maybe I can catch the television cameras before they leave. He runs to the door and flings it open.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: But, Governor, that's not what my people want. The Governor stops in the doorway and turns to Ed Earl.

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: (decidedly) The show's over, Sheriff. Close it down! He runs off and his aides follow. Ed Earl is bitterly disappointed. He turns and exits.

dialogues.speaker: MABEL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Sheriff. You're a good speaker. You could run for office here.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 186
dialogues.text: Ed Earl puts on his hat.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: I was thinking about it, m'am, but I'm just a country sheriff. I'11 never be grown up enough to be in politics. He tips his hat to her and walks outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Governor has just congratulated Melvin on his victory A marching band strikes up the song, Melvin is hoisted on his supporters' shoulders and is marched around the rotun as everybody sings. The flagwaving Dogettes fall in line along with other citizens carrying signs (e.g., "Concerne Citizens for a Whore-Free Society").

The Governor looks down from the first floor landing and, pleased with his handling of the whole situation, he sing his song in counterpoint with the Dogettes.

dialogues.text: (singing) Oooo! I love to Dance the little Sidestep Now they see me Now they don't I've come and gone And oo00000! I love to sweep around A widestep cut a little Swath and lead The people on.

dialogues.text: INT. STATE CAPITOL STAIRCASE — DAY 188 Ed Earl walks down the steps to the ground floor. He look over at the rotunda where Melvin ia getting ready for a l broadcast. The Dogettes and the band are singing their la celebration chorus.

The Sheriff, with one hand, pulls off Melvin's wig, grabs him by the collar and with a grea right punch, smacks him in the jaw. Melvin goes sailing across the polished marble floor and lands in the middle the rotunda, spread-eagled over the Lone Star of Texas.

dialogues.speaker: CHORUS
dialogues.text: «..to victory. Ed Eari walks up to him, drops the wig on his face, steps over the inert body, and exits out the front doors while astonished crowd stares in silence.

dialogues.text: Mornin', Jewel.

dialogues.text: Most of the furniture has been removed or stuck off in a corner covered with sheets. Ed Earl walks inside and look around. ‘The fans on the ceiling have all stopped. He tur as Mona comes down the stairs. They look at each other. They have so much to say it's very difficult to find the words. Mona forces a smile.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: And I want to thank you, Ed Earl, for the protection you gave the girls. You did a fine job in a very difficult situation. Ed Earl walks over to her. He pauses for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Mona, I swear to God I don't understand how this whole thing happened. It was all so fast. It just seems like yesterday that We...

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Ed Earl, the thing to do is put ail this behind you. Quick as you can.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: I just can't figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Look, I made a lotta money, had a few laughs. I danced a bit. Now it's time to pay the fiddler, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Maybe if I just hadn't cussed on that damn television.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: It's over, Ed Earl. Please! She bites her lip to stop from crying. She walks to the window and looks out. Ed Earl comes and stands behind her

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Mona, you've known me now for a long time. You know me better than I know myself. You know how difficult it is for me to say this, but, Mona, I love you. I want to marry you. Mona turns around“into his arms.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Oh, Ed Earl, I've loved you since I was a sixteen-year-old baby and I'll keep on lovin' you ‘til they bury me. They kiss...lovingly and passionately. Mona breaks away.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: But, listen to me, Ed Earl. I've thought about this for a long time now and as much as I would like for it to work, I know deep in my heart it could never be.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: Mona, didn't you hear what I said? She hushes him with her fingers on hie lips.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: I did, my darlin', but it's always going to be the way it is. You'll always be the Sheriff -- and you should be because you're good at your job -- and I'll always be...just what I am. You know it and I know it. It just wouldn't work.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: But we can make it work. I don't give a damn what people say, we've got to give it a chance...please. Don't leave.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: (singing) If I should stay I would only be in your way And go I'11 go and yet I know That I'11 think of you each step of the way And I will always love you I will always love you. Bitter sweet memories I guess that's all I'll be taking with me Good-bye, oh please don't cry ‘Cause we both know that I'm not what you need But I will always love you I will always love you. (talking) And I hope life will treat you kind And I hope that you have ali that you've ever dreamed of.

dialogues.speaker: ED EARL
dialogues.text: I wish you joy, I wish you happiness But above all this I wish you love I love you, and I will always love you. Ed Earl turns and exits. Mona begins to sing, but breaks before the song is finished.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: (singing) 1 will always love you I will always love you, I'll always love you....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jewel comes up to the front porch and speaks softly to Mona.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Come on, honey. It's time to go. Mona brushes away her tears and exits by Jewel, who pulls the front door shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jewel starts up the car and drives down the road. Mona is sadly sitting beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jewel looks into the rearview mirror and sees the Chicken Ranch receding in the background. She looks over at Mona who is lost in her own thoughts. Jewel looks out ahead an sees something that makes her smile. She glances over at Mona again, then smiles some more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pull back from the red light on top of the Sheriff's c and see Ed Earl, with his jacket off and his badge prominently pinned to his shirt, step out of the car and walk around to halt the approaching vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mona looks forward and sees Ed Earl with his hand raised a resolute look of authority on his face. Despite her tears, she breaks into a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jewel stops the car and we pull back as Ed Earl walks ove to Mona and opens her door. The Narrator begins singing a as we swing around and fly higher we see the little house all closed and shuttered sitting forlornly on top of the hill.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Oh, the little house lay ina Green Texas glade Where the trees were as coolin' As fresh lemonade Soft summer wind Had a trace of perfume And a fan was turnin' In every room.

dialogues.speaker: CHORUS
dialogues.text: Twenty fane were turnin’ They were turnin' Twenty fans were turnin’ In every room Fevers were a-burnin' They were burnin' And they had to have A way to cool down.

dialogues.speaker: MONA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: It was just a little old bitty pissant country place....

dialogues.speaker: END CREDITS
dialogues.text: The music begins a foot-stompin' reprise of the songs as we flash short cuts of highlights from the film. At the end the credits, Mona turns to camera.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Ya'll come back now, you hear?
